dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of traveling shots. A well-dressed, pompous-look individual (JOHN DASHWOOD, 35) is making an urgent journe on horseback. He looks anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Norland Park, a large country house built in the early part of the eighteenth century, lies in the moonlit parkland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dim light shed by candles we see a bed in which a (MR DASHWOOD, 52) lies his skin waxy, his breathing labou Around him two silhouettes move and murmur, their clothin susurrating in the deathly hush. DOCTORS. A WOMAN (MRS  DASHWOOD, 50) sits by his side, holding his hand, her eye never leaving his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent) Is John not yet arrived?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We expect him at any moment, dearest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR DASHWOOD looks anguished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls--I have left so little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh, hush, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elinor will try to look after you  all, but make sure she finds a good  husband. The men are such noodles  hereabouts, little wonder none has  pleased her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at each other. MRS DASHWOOD is just managing t conceal her fear and grief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Marianne is sure to find her  storybook hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A romantic poet with flashing eyes  and empty pockets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as she loves him, whoever he  is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret will go to sea and become a  pirate so we need not concern  ourselves with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD tries to laugh but it emerges as a sob. An o MANSERVANT (THOMAS) now enters, anxiety written on every  feature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your son is arrived from London,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR DASHWOOD squeezes his wife's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me speak to John alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods quickly and he smiles at her with infinite  tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, my dear. How happy you have made  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD makes a superhuman effort and smiles back. S allows THOMAS to help her out. She passes JOHN DASHWOOD a he enters, presses his hand, but cannot speak. JOHN takes her place by the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR DASHWOOD summons his last ounces of energy and starts whisper with desperate intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John you will find out soon enough  from my will that the estate of  Norland was left to me in such a way  as prevents me from dividing it  between my families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN blinks. He cannot quite take it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, Father. This is not  good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But MR DASHWOOD continues with even greater determination

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norland in its entirety is therefore  yours by law and I am happy for you  and Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN looks torn between genuine distress and unexpected  delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your stepmother my wife and  daughters are left with only five  hundred pounds a year, barely enough  to live on and nothing for the girls'  dowries. You must help them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN's face is a picture of conflicting emotions. Behind  them is the ominous rustling of parchments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must promise to do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief moment of sincerity overcomes JOHN's natural  hypocrisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise, Father, I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR DASHWOOD seems relieved. Suddenly his breathing change JOHN looks alarmed. He rises and we hear him going to fin the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come! Come quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is we who share the dying man's last words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the house sits a very well-to-do carriage. Behind waits another open carriage upon which servants are layin trunks and boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Help them?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN is standing in mourning clothes and a traveling cape He is watching, and obviously waiting for, a pert WOMAN ( DASHWOOD) who is standing by a mirror looking at him keen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, 'help them'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest, I mean to give them three  thousand pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY goes very still. JOHN gets nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interest will provide them with  a little extra income. Such a gift  will certainly discharge my promise  to my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY slowly turns back to the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, without question! More than  amply...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One had rather, on such occasions,  do too much than too little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause as FANNY turns and looks at him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, he did not stipulate a  particular sum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red-eyed MAID (BETSY) plunges a beautiful muslin frock  into a vat of black dye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD is rushing about, mourning ribbons flapping, putting her knick-knacks into a small valise. The room is chaos. A young WOMAN (ELINOR DASHWOOD) looks on helplessl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be reduced to the condition of  visitor in my own home! It is not to  be borne, Elinor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consider, Mamma! We have nowhere to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Fanny will descend from  London at any moment, followed no  doubt by cartloads of relatives ready  to turn us out of our rooms one by  one do you expect me to be here to  welcome them? Vultures!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly collapses into a chair and bursts into tears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall start making inquiries for a  new house at once. Until then we  must try to bear their coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN and FANNY are on their way out of London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen hundred then. What say you  to fifteen hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brother on earth would do half  so much for his real sisters--let  alone half-blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can hardly expect more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no knowing what they expect.  The question is, what can you afford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful young WOMAN (MARIANNE DASHWOOD) is sitting at the piano playing a particularly sad piece. ELINOR enters

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, cannot you play something  else? Mamma has been weeping since  breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE stops, turns the pages of her music book and sta playing something equally lugubrious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant something less mournful,  dearest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN and FANNY are waiting as the OSTLERS make the final  adjustments to their carriage. The LANDLORD hovers, waiti for a tip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred pounds a year to their  mother while she lives. Would that  be more advisable? It is better than  parting with the fifteen hundred all  at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He displays some coins in his hand. FANNY removes one and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if she should live longer than  fifteen years we would be completely  taken in. People always live forever  when there is an annuity to be paid  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN gives the coins to the LANDLORD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR comes to the foot of a large tree from which a sma staircase issues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, are you there? Please come  down. John and Fanny will be here  soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. ELINOR is about to leave when a disembodied and  truculent young voice stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they coming to live at  Norland? They already have a house  in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because houses go from father to  son, dearest not from father to  daughter. It is the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. ELINOR tries another tack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you come inside, we could play  with your atlas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my atlas any more. It's  their atlas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on ELINOR as she ponders the truth of this statemen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN and FANNY joggle on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty pounds now and then will amply  discharge my promise, you are quite  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Although to say the truth, I  am convinced within myself that your  father had no idea of your giving  them money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will have five hundred a year  amongst them as it is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and what on earth can four women  want for more than that? Their  housekeeping will be nothing at all  they will have no carriage, no horses,  hardly any servants and will keep no  company. Only conceive how comfortable  they will be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large contingent of SERVANTS who staff Norland Park a gathered in gloomy silence as ELINOR addresses them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you know, we are looking for a  new home. When we leave we shall be  able to retain only Thomas and Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM holds on THOMAS and BETSY, a capable woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are very sorry to have to leave  you all. But we are certain you will  find the new Mrs Dashwood a fair and  generous mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN and FANNY's carriage approaches Norland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will be much more able to give  you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN and FANNY are about to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we are agreed. No money but the  occasional gift of game and fish in  season will be very welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father would be proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire family, with the exception of MARGARET, is pre BETSY is serving food in an atmosphere of stiff silence.  Cutlery clinks. JOHN chews loudly. MARIANNE is rigid with resentment. MRS DASHWOOD maintains a cool, removed dignit ELINOR tries to play hostess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Mrs Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother is always in excellent  health, thank you. My brother Robert  is in town with her this season and  quite the most popular bachelor in  London! He has his own barouche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the brief silence which follows this, FANNY surreptiti checks the hallmark on her butterknife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have two brothers, have you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, yes. Edward is the eldest  Mamma quite depends upon him. He is  traveling up from Plymouth shortly  and will break his journey here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD looks at ELINOR pointedly. JOHN notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to MRS DASHWOOD) If that is agreeable to you, of  course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear John this is your home now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY looks about, barely able to conceal her satisfactio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is sitting with a little pile of parcels. She puts shawl into some paper and ties it with ribbon as MARIANNE thunders in, looking mutinous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny wishes to know where the key  for the silver cabinet is kept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betsy has it, I think. What does  Fanny want with the silver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only presume she wants to count  it. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Presents for the servants. Have you  seen Margaret? I am worried about  her. She has taken to hiding in the  oddest places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortunate girl. At least she can  escape Fanny, which is more than any  of us is able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do your best. You have not said  a word to her for a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (truculently) I have! I have said 'yes' and 'no'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY, MRS DASHWOOD, ELINOR and JOHN are at breakfast.  MARIANNE enters. ELINOR catches her eye and indicates FAN with a slight motion of her head. MARIANNE makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very polite) Good morning, Fanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY is rather startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fanny) How did you find the silver? Is it  all genuine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR rushes in before MARIANNE gets any further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray, when may we expect the pleasure  of your brother's company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward is due tomorrow. And my dear  Mrs Dashwood, in view of the fact  that he will not be with us for long,  I wondered if Miss Margaret would  mind giving up her room to him the  view is quite incomparable from her  windows and I should so much like  Edward to see Norland at its best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE slams her cup down and throws a furious look at  ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MARIANNE are removing MARGARET's toys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intolerable woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is but one consolation if Edward  is anything like Fanny, we shall be  only too happy to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very capable HORSEMAN (EDWARD FERRARS) canters up the g drive. CLOSE on his face as he gazes up at the elegant faГ§ade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone except MARGARET is present. EDWARD has just shak bands with ELINOR. He behaves with great respect to the  DASHWOODS and seems embarrassed by FANNY's pro prietorial air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where is Miss Margaret? I declare,  Mrs Dashwood, I am beginning to doubt  of her existence! She must run  positively wild!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive us, Mr Ferrars. My youngest  is not to be found this morning. She  is a little shy of strangers at  present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally. I am also shy of strangers  and I have nothing like her excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dangerous) How do you like your view, Mr Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR glances at her warningly but EDWARD replies with  careful consideration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very much. Your stables are very  handsome and beautifully kept, Mrs  Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stables! Edward--your windows overlook  the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oversight, Fanny, led me to the  wrong room. I have rectified the  situation and am happily settled in  the guest quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE and ELINOR look at each other in surprise. FANNY looks furious. MRS DASHWOOD smiles warmly at EDWARD. CLOSE on ELINOR. She is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY is walking with EDWARD, who looks at the pictures w interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all exceedingly spoilt, I  find. Miss Margaret spends all her  time up trees and under furniture  and I have barely had a civil word  from Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Fanny, they have just lost  their father their lives will never  be the same again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is no excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY leads EDWARD in. She sniffs with distaste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have never liked the smell of books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? No. The dust, perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they speak, EDWARD notices a large atlas retreating  apparently all by itself across the floor. Someone is  obviously under the table, pulling it out of sight. He  registers it and immediately moves in such a way as to sh it from FANNY. He turns back, searching for something to  divert her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you have great plans for the  walnut grove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes! I shall have it pulled down  to make room for a Grecian temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a stifled wail from under the table, which EDWAR covers with a cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How picturesque. Will you show me  the site?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he ushers FANNY out, flicking a quick glance over his shoulder at the fugitive's foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR, MRS DASHWOOD and MARIANNE are sitting round a tab with a pile of letters. ELINOR is handing one back to her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too expensive. We do not need four  bedrooms, we can share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR reads the letter quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, we have only five hundred  pounds a year. I will send out more  inquiries today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. Hesitantly, EDWARD appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon my intrusion, but I believe I  have found what you are looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE and MRS DASHWOOD are puzzled by his elliptical m but ELINOR immediately understands and rises, in smiling  relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD is standing outside keeping a discreet lookout. Th door is half open and he can hear ELINOR trying to coax  MARGARET out. FANNY walks by with a BUTLER to whom she is giving instructions. EDWARD pretends to examine the mould and she passes on unsuspecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you come out, dearest? We  haven't seen you all day. Mamma is  very concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More silence. EDWARD thinks hard. He makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD walks in loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Dashwood! Excuse me I was  wondering do you by any chance have  such a thing as a reliable atlas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks up at him in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. I wish to check the  position of the Nile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD appears to be utterly sincere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister says it is in South America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From under the table we hear a snort. ELINOR looks at him realisation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! No, no indeed. She is quite wrong.  For I believe it is in--in Belgium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belgium? Surely not. You must be  thinking of the Volga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from under the table) The Volga?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. The Volga, which, as you  know, starts in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vladivostok, and ends in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St Albans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. Where the coffee beans come  from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are having such a good time that it is rather a pity the game is stopped by the appearance from under the tabl of MARGARET who reveals herself to be a disheveled girl o eleven. She hauls the atlas up and plonks it in front of  EDWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The source of the Nile is in  Abyssinia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? Good heavens. How do you do.  Edward Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD shakes MARGARET's hand solemnly and looks over her head at ELINOR. They smile at each other, a connection ma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN is reading a newspaper. MRS DASHWOOD sits across fro FANNY, who thumbs through a fashion-plate magazine. ELINO is at a desk by the window writing a letter we see the wo 'of course we should like to leave as soon as possible'.  Suddenly she hears a commotion outside. MARGARET runs pas the window brandishing a stick. EDWARD follows, and proce to teach her the first principles of sword-fighting. They feint and parry, EDWARD serious and without a hint of  condescension, MARGARET concentrating furiously. EDWARD  suddenly turns, as though feeling ELINOR's gaze. She smil but looks away quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD comes into the doorway and sees ELINOR who is list to MARIANNE playing a concerto. ELINOR stands in a gracef rather sad attitude, her back to us. Suddenly she senses  EDWARD behind her and turns. He is about to turn away,  embarrassed to have been caught admiring her, when he see she has been weeping. Hastily she tries to dry her eyes. comes forward and offers her a handkerchief, which she ta with a grateful smile. We notice his monogram in the corn ECF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetic) That was my father's favourite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD nods kindly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for your help with  Margaret, Mr Ferrars. She is a changed  girl since your arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. I enjoy her company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has she shown you her tree-house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. Would you do me the honour,  Miss Dashwood? It is very fine out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to walk out of shot, still talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret has always wanted to travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. She is heading an expedition  to China shortly. I am to go as her  servant but only on the understanding  that I will be very badly treated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What will your duties be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sword-fighting, administering rum  and swabbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM tilts up to find MRS DASHWOOD on the middle landing o the staircase, smiling down at them. CAM tilts up yet fur to find FANNY on the landing above, watching EDWARD and E with a face like a prune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD and ELINOR are still talking as they walk arm in a in the late afternoon sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I want--all I have ever wanted  is the quiet of a private life but  my mother is determined to see me  distinguished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hardly knows. Any fine figure  will suit a great orator, a leading  politician, even a barrister would  serve, but only on the condition  that I drive my own barouche and  dine in the first circles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone is light but there is an underlying bitterness t it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you wish for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always preferred the church, but  that is not smart enough for my mother  she prefers the army, but that is a  great deal too smart for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you stay in London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate London. No peace. A country  living is my ideal a small parish  where I might do some good, keep  chickens and give very short sermons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD and ELINOR are on horseback. The atmosphere is  intimate, the quality of the conversation rooted now in t affections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk of feeling idle and useless  imagine how that is compounded when  one has no choice and no hope  whatsoever of any occupation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD nods and smiles at the irony of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our circumstances are therefore  precisely the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except that you will inherit your  fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her slightly shocked but enjoying her boldnes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot even earn ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps Margaret is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piracy is our only option.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride on in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is swabbing exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is over. JOHN and FANNY are examining plans of the Norland estate, looking for somewhere to build a hermitag EDWARD is reading out loud. ELINOR embroiders and listens MRS DASHWOOD and MARIANNE make up the rest of the audienc the latter in a state of high impatience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No voice divine the storm allayed No  light propitious shone, When snatched  from all effectual aid, We perished  each alone: But I beneath a rougher  sea, And whelmed in deeper gulfs  than he.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE jumps up and goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Edward! Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the book from him and reads the stanza with  passionate brio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you not feel his despair? Try  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather mortified, EDWARD starts again, but not before  receiving a sympathetic look from ELINOR which seems to  comfort him a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD is ruminating sadly. MARIANNE rushes in hold a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma, look. This has just arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from the  letter) 'I should be pleased to offer you a  home at Barton Cottage as soon as  ever you have need of it' why, it is  from my cousin, Sir John Middleton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Elinor must approve the rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD looks at the letter again and thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Elinor not yet seen this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I will fetch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. No. Let us delay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think--I believe that Edward and  Elinor have formed an attachment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne nods, a little reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be cruel to take her away  so soon and Devonshire is so far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD makes her decision. She takes the letter and hides it in the pocket of her gown. MARIANNE looks on  frowningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so grave? Do you disapprove her  choice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By no means. Edward is very amiable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amiable but?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is something wanting. He  is too sedate his reading last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elinor has not your feelings, his  reserve suits her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE thinks for a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can he love her? Can the ardour of  the soul really be satisfied with  such polite, concealed affections?  To love is to burn to be on fire,  all made of passion, of adoration,  of sacrifice! Like Juliet, or  Guinevere or Heloise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They made rather pathetic ends, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pathetic! To die for love? How can  you say so? What could be more  glorious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that may be taking your  romantic sensibilities a little far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more I know of the world, the  more I am convinced that I shall  never see a man whom I can truly  love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You require so much!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not! I require only what any  young woman of taste should a man  who sings well, dances admirably,  rides bravely, reads with passion  and whose tastes agree in every point  with my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is in bed, deep in thought. MARIANNE enters in her nightclothes, carrying a book of poetry. She reads, teasi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is love a fancy, or a feeling? No It  is immortal as immaculate truth 'Tis  not a blossom shed as soon as Youth  Drops from the stem of life for it  will grow In barren regions, where  no waters flow Nor ray of promise  cheats the pensive gloom--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps onto the bed. ELINOR smiles somewhat suspicious

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a pity it is that Edward has no  passion for reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was you who asked him to read and  then you made him nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your behaviour to him in all  other respects is perfectly cordial  so I must assume that you like him  in spite of his deficiencies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying hard) I think him everything that is amiable  and worthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise indeed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he shall have my unanswering  devotion when you tell me he is to  be my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is greatly taken aback and does not know how to re Suddenly MARIANNE hugs her passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How shall I do without you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do without me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE pulls away, her eyes full of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure you will be very happy.  But you must promise not to live too  far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, there is no question of  that is, there is no under standing  between...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR trails off. MARIANNE looks at her keenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bold clarity of this question discomforts ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not attempt to deny that I think  very highly of him that I greatly  esteem that I like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Esteem him! Like him! Use those  insipid words again and I shall leave  the room this instant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes ELINOR laugh in spite of her discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Forgive me. Believe my  feelings to be stronger than I have  declared but further than that you  must not believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is flummoxed but she rallies swiftly and picks u her book again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Is love a fancy or a feeling?' Or a  Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR blushes in good earnest. MARIANNE goes to the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Elinor) 'I do not attempt to deny that I  think highly of him greatly esteem  him! Like him!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she is gone, leaving ELINOR both agitated and amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY is standing by the window looking out. We see her P of ELINOR and EDWARD walking in the garden. MRS DASHWOOD enters, pauses for a moment and then joins F at the window. FANNY pretends not to have been watching b MRS DASHWOOD looks down at the lovers and then smiles swe at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all so happy that you chose  to invite Edward to Norland. He is a  dear boy and we are all very fond of  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY does a bit of quick thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have great hopes for him. Much is  expected of him by our mother with  regard to his profession

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in marriage. She is determined  that both he and Robert will marry  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. But I hope she desires  them to marry for love, first and  foremost? I have always felt that,  contrary to common wisdom, true  affection is by far the most valuable  dowry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love is all very well, but  unfortunately we cannot always rely  on the heart to lead us in the most  suitable directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY lowers her voice confidingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, my dear Mrs Dashwood, Edward  is entirely the kind of compassionate  person upon whom penniless women can  prey--and having entered into any  kind of understanding, he would never  go back on his word. He is quite  simply incapable of doing so. But it  would lead to his ruin. I worry for  him so, Mrs Dashwood. My mother has  always made it perfectly plain that  she will withdraw all financial  support from Edward, should he choose  to plant his affections in less...  exalted ground than he deserves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is impossible for MRS DASHWOOD not to get the point. S is appalled and furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sweeps off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD, breathless with rage, is searching through wardrobe for the gown which contains SIR JOHN's letter. F fly hither and thither. Finally MRS DASHWOOD plunges her  hand into the right pocket and withdraws the letter. She  looks at it, suddenly concerned and anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire family is present. Everyone is watching MRS  DASHWOOD, who has just made her announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Devonshire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is devastated. FANNY is thrilled. MRS DASHWOOD looks a him with compassion and then at ELINOR, who is trying to  keep calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin Sir John Middleton has  offered us a small house on his  estate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir John Middleton? What is his  situation? He must be a man of  property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is a widower. He lives with his  mother-in-law at Barton Park and it  is Barton Cottage that he offers us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a cottage! How charming. A little  cottage is always very snug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you will not leave before the  summer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear Edward, we can no longer  trespass upon your sister's good  will. We must leave as soon as  possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will come and stay with us,  Edward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should like that very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward has long been expected in  town by our mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD ignores FANNY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come as soon as you can, Edward.  Remember that you are always welcome.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. NORLAND PARK
dialogues.text: ELINOR has come to say goodbye to her HORSE. She strokes soft face sadly. Then she senses someone and turns to fin EDWARD standing nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cannot you take him with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cannot possibly afford him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps he could make himself useful  in the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR tries to smile. EDWARD looks at her for a long mom and then comes closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Dashwood--Elinor. I must talk  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The use of her Christian name--and in such a loving tone- stops ELINOR's breath altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something of great importance  I need... to tell you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes closer still. The HORSE breathes between them. E is on fire with anticipation but EDWARD looks troubled an has less the air of a suitor than he might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --about--about my education.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Your education?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It was less... successful than  it might have been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD laughs nervously. ELINOR is completely bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was conducted in Plymouth--oddly  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plymouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--well--I spent four years there-- at a school run by a--a Mr Pratt--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pratt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is beginning to feel like a parrot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely--Mr Pratt--and there, I-- that is to say, he has a--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As EDWARD flounders, a familiar voice cuts through this  unexpected foray into his academic past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward! Edward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to find FANNY powering down upon them, waving a letter. EDWARD steps back, glancing almost guiltily at EL who is as confused as we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been all over for you! You  are needed in London this instant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fanny, I am leaving this afternoon  as it is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, that will not do. Family  affairs are in chaos owing to your  absence. Mother is quite adamant  that you should leave at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY is determined. She obviously has no intention of le him alone with ELINOR. EDWARD turns to ELINOR, frustratio in every muscle, his jaw set tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY drags EDWARD off, leaving ELINOR to gaze sadly afte them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DASHWOODS are on their way. The mood is very sombre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward promised he would bring the  atlas to Barton for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks at ELINOR, pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he? Well, I will wager he will  do so in less than a fortnight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD looks at ELINOR with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage rolls on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we there yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In comparison to Norland, Barton Cottage has the air of a damp shoebox. it sits low and bleak in the grey lonely  countryside. From one side we can see the DASHWOODS' carriage drawing at the gate. From the other, a much grander vehicle, from which loud whooping can be heard, is approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the exhausted DASHWOODS alight, they converge with a r complexioned MAN in a redingote (SIR JOHN MIDDLETON) and rotund, equally roseate LADY (MRS JENNINGS) who have fall over each other in their haste to get out of their carria

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN clasps her hands and starts to help her up the p followed by ELINOR, MARIANNE and MARGARET, who is clearly fascinated by his bouncy companion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear ladies, dear ladies, upon my  word, here you are, here you are,  here you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir John, your extraordinary kindness--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, none of that, hush, please, none  of that, but here is my dear mamma- in-law Mrs Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the journey tolerable, you poor  souls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not come up to the Park  first and take your ease? We saw you  pass--Like many people who live rather  lonely lives together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN and MRS JENNINGS talk incessantly, interrupt eac other all the time and never listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but I would not wait for you to  come to us, I made John call for the  carriage--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would not wait, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --as we get so little company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the front door and BETSY's smiling welcome. In the confusion of milling people and THOMAS carrying the  lighter luggage, MARIANNE contrives to slip into the hous alone. We follow her but hear the conversation continuing V.O. MARIANNE looks about the parlour, where a dismal fir is smoking. She starts up the stairs, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I feel as if I know you already-- delightful creatures!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delightful! And you know you are to  dine at Barton Park every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but dear Sir John, we cannot--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no no no no no no no, I shall  not brook refusals. I am quite deaf  to 'em, you know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --deaf--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE enters a small bedroom. She sits on the bed. The she goes to the window and opens it. Voices float up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I insist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us only settle in for a few days,  Sir John, and thank you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no thankings, no, please, can't  bear 'em, embarrassing, you know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE closes the window and crosses the corridor to an bed room--similarly stark. She sighs and turns back down stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will send game and fruit as a  matter of course--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --fruit and game--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and the carriage is at your beck  and call--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE joins the group, who are now in the parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --call--and here is Miss Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you disappear to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I declare you are the loveliest girl  I ever set eyes on! Cannot you get  them married, Mrs Dashwood? You must  not leave it too long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, alas, there are no smart young  men hereabouts to woo them--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --not a beau for miles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The strain of exhibiting joy and gratitude is beginning t tell on MRS DASHWOOD who is sagging visibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Mother, let us leave them in  peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is Colonel Brandon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN is dragging her down the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent fellow! We served in the  East India Regiment together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wait till he sees you! If we  can persuade him out to meet you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reclusive individual. But you are  fatigued. I can see that you are  fatigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now he is pushing her into the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she is fatigued!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along, Mother, we really must  leave them to themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must get your maidservant to  make you up some camphor--it is the  best tonic for the staggers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send Thomas to us for the carriage  when you are ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take off, waving wildly. MARGARET goes down the path watch them and turns back to her slightly stunned family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakly) What generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. I am surprised they did not  offer us their clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE and ELINOR are getting undressed for bed. it's v cold. They keep their underclothing on and get in, shiver at the bony chill of the linen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETSY is pinning out laundry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET tries to climb an impossible tree. Her petticoat snag and tear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks out of the window at the wild countryside. Uncon sciously, one hand plays up and down on the sill as though it were a keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR sits at a little desk counting money and making no BETSY enters to clean out the fire. She notices the money

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar is five shilling a pound these  parts, Miss Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) No more sugar then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on MRS DASHWOOD looking out of the window, thinking She remembers MRS JENNINGS's words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a beau for miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD turns into the room to look at her brood. EL and MARIANNE are mending MARGARET's petticoats. CLOSE on mother's anxious expression--what is to become of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of SIR JOHN's house--a very comfortable looking country seat with fine grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can Brandon be, poor fellow? I  hope he has not lamed his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on an empty chair and place setting. Pull out to re the DASHWOODS at their first dinner with SIR JOHN and MRS JENNINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon is the most eligible  bachelor in the county--he is bound  to do for one of you. Mind, he is a  better age for Miss Dashwood--but I  dare say she left her heart behind  in Sussex, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE flashes an unmistakable glance of alarmed concer at her sister, which MRS JENNINGS notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha! I see you, Miss Marianne! I  think I have unearthed a secret!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oho! Have you sniffed one out already,  Mother? You are worse than my best  pointer, Flossie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both laugh immoderately. ELINOR tries to stay calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of man is he, Miss Dashwood?  Is he butcher, baker, candlestick- maker? I shall winkle it out of you  somehow, you know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's horribly good at winkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are in lonely country now, Miss  Dashwood, none of us has any secrets  here--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --or if we do, we do not keep them  for long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR tries to smile. MARIANNE looks furious. MARGARET i staring at MRS JENNINGS as if she were some particularly  thrilling form of wildlife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is curate of the parish, I dare  say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or a handsome lieutenant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us a clue, Miss Dashwood--is he  in uniform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR starts to change the subject, but MARGARET interru her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has no profession!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN and MRS JENNINGS turn on her with screams of del ELINOR, MARIANNE and MRS DASHWOOD look at each other  helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No profession! A gentleman, then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with daggers) Margaret, you know perfectly well  there is no such person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is! There is! And his name  begins with an F!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks hard at her plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD is appalled at her youngest's relish for suc vulgar game. SIR JOHN and MRS JENNINGS are cock-a-hoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F indeed! A very promising letter.  Let me--F, F, Fo, Fa... Upon my word,  but I cannot think of a single name  beginning with F--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forrest? Foster? Frost? Foggarty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE suddenly stands up. SIR JOHN and MRS JENNINGS ar so surprised they stop talking. Everyone stares at MARIAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlled fury) Sir John, might I play your  pianoforte?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, yes--my goodness. We do  not stand on ceremony here, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For once, ELINOR is grateful for her sister's rudeness as everyone rises and follows MARIANNE out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soldierly MAN of about forty (COLONEL BRANDON) is  dismounting from his horse. From within we hear MARIANNE' song begin. His head snaps up to the windows. An expressi of pained surprise comes into his melancholy, brooding ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone watches MARIANNE as she plays and sings. Behind  them we see BRANDON entering. But he stays in the shadow the door and no one notices him. CLOSE on his face. He ga at MARIANNE with an unfathomable look of grief and longin He breathes in deeply. Suddenly, ELINOR feels his presenc and looks around at him. After a few moments, she turns b slightly puzzled. The song finishes. Everyone claps. The ventures out into the light and SIR JOHN springs from his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon! Where have you been? Come,  come and meet our beautiful new  neighbours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a pity you are late, Colonel!  You have missed the most delightful  singing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON bows to the company and smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great pity, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks at him, even more puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Dashwood, may I present my dear  friend Colonel Brandon? We served  together in the East Indies and I  assure you there is no better fellow  on earth--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you really been to the East  Indies, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is quivering with fascination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like? Hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But COLONEL BRANDON knows what MARGARET wants to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mysteriously) The air is full of spices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET smiles with satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Miss Dashwood--it is your turn  to entertain us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, Sir John, I do not--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and I think we can all guess what  key you will sing in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN and MRS JENNINGS are bursting with their new jok

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F major!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DASHWOODS are returning home. A row is in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Margaret) As for you, you have no right, no  right at all, to parade your ignorant  assumptions--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are not assumptions. You told  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR stares at MARIANNE. MARIANNE colours and attacks  MARGARET again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you nothing--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll meet him when he comes,  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not the point. You do not  speak of such things before strangers--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But everyone else was--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Jennings is not everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like her! She talks about things.  We never talk about things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush, please, now that is enough,  Margaret. If you cannot think of  anything appropriate to say, you  will please restrict your remarks to  the weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heated pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like Colonel Brandon too. He's  been to places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background, SIR JOHN, ELINOR and MRS JENNINGS pack the remains of a picnic into a basket. MRS DASHWOOD and  MARGARET examine a foxhole. In the foreground, MARIANNE i cutting bulrushes for basketwork. Her knife is blunt and saws impatiently. COLONEL BRANDON materialises at her side and wordlessly o her his hunting knife. Oddly nervous, MARIANNE takes it. turns back to the rushes and cuts them with ease. The  COLONEL's gaze follows her movements as if held by a magn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN and BRANDON are cleaning their guns in companion silence--a habit left over from army days. SIR JOHN eyes  BRANDON roguishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what they're saying, of  course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word is that you have developed  a taste for--certain company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON stays resolutely silent. SIR JOHN is emboldened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why not, say I. A man like you-- in his prime--she'd be a most  fortunate young lady--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON cuts across him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne Dashwood would no more think  of me than she would of you, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandon, my boy, do not think of  yourself so meanly--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all the better for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR JOHN subsides. BRANDON is clearly as angry with himse as he is with SIR JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON strides along in hunting gear, a gun slung under arm, his dog trotting behind him with a duck clamped betw its jaws. The bulrushes catch his eye and he slows, then  stops. He stands for a moment deep in thought. Then he ta his hunting knife, cuts one and walks off contemplatively

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An outdoor luncheon is in progress. COLONEL BRANDON is ta to MRS DASHWOOD. Occasionally he looks over towards MARIA who is playing bilboquet with SIR JOHN and MARGARET. MRS  JENNINGS nudges ELINOR hard and gestures to BRANDON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stage whisper) Besotted! Excellent match, for he is  rich and she is handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you known the Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord bless you, as long as ever  I have been here, and I came fifteen  years back. His estate at Delaford  is but four miles hence and he and  John are very thick. He has no wife  or children of his own, for--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS lowers her voice to a stentorian whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --he has a tragic history. He loved  a girl once--twenty years ago now--a  ward to his family, but they were  not permitted to marry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what grounds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money. Eliza was poor. When the father  discovered their amour, she was flung  out of the house and he packed off  into the army. I believe he would  have done himself a harm if not for  John...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What became of the lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she was passed from man to man-- disappeared from all good society.  When Brandon got back from India he  searched for heaven knows how long,  only to find her dying in a poor  house. You have seen how it has  affected him. Once I thought my  daughter Charlotte might have cheered  him up, but she is much better off  where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is silent with amazement at this unexpected histor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him now, though. So attentive.  I shall try an experiment on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, please, dear Mrs Jennings,  leave the poor Colonel alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it is just the thing--all  suitors need a little help, my dear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS winks at ELINOR and rubs her hands as though about to perform a magic trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trillingly) Colonel Brandon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have not heard you play for us of  late!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the simple reason that you have  a far superior musician here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates MARIANNE, who smiles absently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you did not know, Miss  Marianne, that our dear Brandon shares  your passion for music and plays the  piano forte very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks at BRANDON in some surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play us a duet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON looks at MRS JENNINGS warningly but she ignores h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll trow you know quite as many  melancholy tunes as Miss Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her tone is so knowing that MARIANNE frowns uncomfortably

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come! Let us see you both side by  side!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE rises impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not know any duets. Forgive me,  Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away. MRS JENNINGS chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DASHWOODS returning. MARIANNE is taking her bonnet of so furiously that she simply gets the knot tighter and  tighter. Despite them selves, ELINOR and MRS DASHWOOD are amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Are we never to have a moment's  peace? The rent here may be low but  I think we have it on very hard terms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Jennings is a wealthy woman with  a married daughter--she has nothing  to do but marry off everyone else's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETSY pokes her head out from the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a parcel arrived for you,  Miss Dashwood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A parcel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all crowd into the dining room to find a large packa on the table, which MARGARET is permitted to open. In the meantime ELINOR comes to the rescue with the bonnet and  MARIANNE stands shifting like a spirited mare as ELINOR  patiently unravels the knot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is too ridiculous! When is a man  to be safe from such wit if age and  infirmity do not protect him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Infirmity!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Colonel Brandon is infirm, then I  am at death's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a miracle your life has extended  this far...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not hear him complain of a  rheumatism in his shoulder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight ache' I believe was his  phrase...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE smiles and ELINOR laughs at her. Then MARGARET o the parcel to reveal--her atlas. The atmosphere alters  immediately as MRS DASHWOOD and MARIANNE look at ELINOR i consternation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Edward said he would bring it  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a letter on top of the atlas. CLOSE on the addre 'To the Dashwoods'. MRS DASHWOOD picks it up, looks at EL and opens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dear Mrs Dashwood, Miss Dashwood,  Miss Marianne and Captain Margaret-- it gives me great pleasure to restore  this atlas to its rightful owner.  Alas, business in London does not  permit me to accompany it, although  this is likely to hurt me far more  than it hurts you. For the present  my memories of your kindness must be  enough to sustain me, and I remain  your devoted servant always. E. C.  Ferrars.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence greets this brief epistle. ELINOR struggles to  contain her bitter disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why hasn't he come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he is busy, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he'd come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is genuinely upset. ELINOR quietly hangs up  MARIANNE's bonnet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why hasn't he come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD looks beseechingly at MARIANNE, who nods and grasps MARGARET's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am taking you for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I've been a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is going to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE shoves her bonnet back on and drags MARGARET out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not going to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that and then it always  does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the front door slam behind them. There is a short silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fear Mrs Jennings is a bad  influence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She approaches ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must miss him, Elinor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks very directly at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not engaged, Mamma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he loves you, dearest, of that I  am certain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks down. She speaks slowly, choosing her words  with care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am by no means assured of his regard  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Elinor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But even were he to feel such a...  preference, I think we should be  foolish to assume that there would  not be many obstacles to his choosing  a woman of no rank who cannot afford  to buy sugar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Elinor--your heart must tell you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In such a situation, Mamma, it is  perhaps better to use one's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clears her throat, rises determinedly, picks up the  accounts book and opens it. MRS DASHWOOD is silenced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE walks very briskly, dragging an unwilling MARGAR behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has started to rain. Mists are gathering around the tw figures walking against the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any felicity in the world  superior to this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you it would rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! There is some blue sky! Let us  chase it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not supposed to run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE runs off down the hill into the heart of the mis MARGARET stumbles after her, grumbling. We follow MARIANN in her headlong descent and suddenly, dramatically, she t and sprawls to the ground, letting out a sharp cry of pai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to get up, but the pain in her ankle is too gre She sinks back to the ground. MARGARET is very alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, run home and fetch help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mists have thickened. They can no longer see where th are. Despite her rising fear, MARGARET squares her should bravely and tries to sense the direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is this way. I will run  as fast as I can, Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dashes off. As she goes into the mist we hear the thu of hooves. CU Margaret's terrified expression. They seem to be comin from all around. She wheels and turns and then--Crash! Th the mist breaks a huge white horse. Astride sits an Adoni in hunting gear. MARGARET squeals. The horse rears. Its r controls it and slides off. He rushes to MARIANNE's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (transfixed) Only my ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have your permission to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He indicates her leg. Decorous, perhaps faintly impish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --ascertain if there are any breaks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE nods speechlessly. With great delicacy, he feels her ankle. MARGARET's eyes are out on chapel-hooks. MARIA almost swoons with embarrassment and excitement mixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not broken. Now, can you put  your arm about my neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE does not need any encouragement. He lifts her  effortlessly and calls to his horse: 'Bedivere!' It trots obediently forward. The STRANGER smiles down at MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allow me to escort you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain is thudding against the window from which MRS DASHWO turns, looking very worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne was sure it would not rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which invariably means it will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can see she is trying to conceal her anxiety from mother. There are noises in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET runs into the room dripping wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fell over! She fell down--and  he's carrying her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD and ELINOR rush to the front door. They see STRANGER carrying MARIANNE up the garden path, his scarle coat staining the monochrome rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STRANGER reaches the door. This is no time for  introductions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here, sir--this way. Margaret,  open the door wider. Please, sir,  lay her here. Marianne, are you in  pain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move into the parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is carried in, surrounded by ELINOR, MRS DASHWOO and MARGARET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a twisted ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not be alarmed, Mamma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STRANGER deposits MARIANNE on the sofa. They look str into each other's eyes. Electric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you it is not serious.  I took the liberty of feeling the  bone and it is perfectly sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR raises her eyebrows at MARIANNE, who blushes to he roots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I cannot even begin to thank  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please do not think of it. I'm  honoured of be of service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you not be seated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray excuse me--I have no desire to  leave a water mark! But permit me to  call tomorrow afternoon and inquire  after the patient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall look forward to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to MARIANNE and smiles. She smiles back glorious He bows, and sweeps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hissing) His name! His name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD silences her with a gesture and follows him with all the solicitous charm she can command while MARGA pokes her head around the door to watch. ELINOR is removi MARIANNE's boot and trying not to laugh at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD calls out after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell us to whom we are so  much obliged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STRANGER mounts Bedivere and turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Willoughby of Allenham--your  servant, ma'am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he gallops off into the mist--we almost expect Bedive to sprout wings. CLOSE on MRS DASHWOOD's excited expressi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD runs back into the parlour, jittering with  excitement and anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr John Willoughby of Allenham!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What an impressive gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifted me as if I weighed no more  than a dried leaf!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he human?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE hits ELINOR. MRS DASHWOOD tends to her ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me if I hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regarding Marianne's  ecstatic expression) She feels no pain, Mamma. Margaret,  ask Betsy to make up a cold compress,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving reluctantly) Did you see him? He expressed himself  well, did he not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With great decorum and honour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And spirit and wit and feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And economy--ten words at most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From below stairs we can hear MARGARET wailing Wait for m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he is to come tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must change, Marianne--you will  catch a cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What care I for colds when there is  such a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will care very much when your  nose swells up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are right. Help me, Elinor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET comes back with the bandages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What has happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have decided to give you to the  Gypsies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MARIANNE go upstairs. MARGARET whispers to MRS DASHWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they be married before Edward  and Elinor, do you think, Mamma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, you are worse than Mrs  Jennings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has cleared. SIR JOHN's horse munches grass  contentedly by the side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Willoughby is well worth catching,  Miss Dashwood--Miss Marianne must  not expect to have all the men to  herself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DASHWOODS are having a frustrating time winkling  information about WILLOUGHBY out of SIR JOHN, who is in t only anxious to protect BRANDON's interest. MARIANNE has bandaged foot up on the sofa and is fast losing patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what do you know of Mr Willoughby,  Sir John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decent shot--and there is not a bolder  rider in all England.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what is he like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are his tastes? His passions?  His pursuits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mystified) Well, he has the nicest little bitch  of a pointer--was she out with him  yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE gives up. MRS DASHWOOD takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Allenham, Sir John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice little estate three miles east.  He is to inherit it from an elderly  relative--Lady Allen is her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they are getting somewhere. MARIANNE is about to ask  another question when they hear a horse galloping up. Eve is electrified. MARGARET runs to the window and turns bac in disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Colonel Brandon. I shall go  outside and keep watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET runs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are all on the lookout for  Willoughby, eh? Dear me, poor Brandon.  You will none of you think of him  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON is admitted by BETSY. He is carrying a large bunc of hothouse flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is the invalid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands MARIANNE the flowers with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rather absently hands the flowers to ELINOR, who goes for a vase. SIR JOHN gestures at BRANDON with bluff  insensitivity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Marianne, I cannot see why you  should set your cap at Mr Willoughby  when you have already made such a  splendid conquest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no intention of 'setting my  cap' at anyone, Sir John!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Willoughby--Lady Allen's nephew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
