dialogues.text: BRANDON's light tone betrays no emotion. ELINOR comes bac in with the flowers and puts them on the table next to  MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, he visits every year for he is  to inherit Allenham--and he has a  very pretty estate of his own, Miss  Dashwood, Combe Magna in Somerset.  If I were you, I would not give him  up to my younger sister in spite of  all this tumbling down hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly MARGARET runs in screaming 'Marianne's preserver at the top of her voice. Everyone starts to move at once. MARGARET is silenced. BRANDON looks at MARIANNE, whose  incandescent expression makes her feelings all too clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is the man himself. Come, Brandon-- we know when we are not wanted. Let  us leave him to the ladies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne! Sir John and the Colonel  are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks up, suddenly self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Colonel. Thank you for the  flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR sees them out. We hear WILLOUGHBY's voice outside. CLOSE on MARIANNE's radiant anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY is shaking hands with COLONEL BRANDON and SIR  JOHN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does he do? How do you do, more  like. Go on in, they're waiting for  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON looks at WILLOUGHBY for a moment. He bows. WILLOU bows. Then BRANDON and SIR JOHN exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR leads in WILLOUGHBY. MRS DASHWOOD greets him with  outstretched arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Willoughby! What a pleasure to  see you again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pleasure is all mine, I can  asstire you. I trust Miss Marianne  has not caught cold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have found out my name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. The neighbourhood is  crawling with my spies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly produces a bunch of wild flowers from behind back and offers them to MARIANNE with a courtly, humorous bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And since you cannot venture out to  nature, nature must be brought to  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How beautiful. These are not from  the hothouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY sees BRANDON's flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! I see mine is not the first  offering, nor the most elegant. I am  afraid I obtained these from an  obliging field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have always preferred wild  flowers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suspected as much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR takes the delicate flowers from WILLOUGHBY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will put these in water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our gratitude, Mr Willoughby, is  beyond expression--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is I who am grateful. I have  often passed this cottage and grieved  for its lonely state--and then the  first news I had from Lady Allen  when I arrived was that it was taken.  I felt a peculiar interest in the  event which nothing can account for  but my present delight in meeting  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is merry, spirited, voluble--a breath of fresh air. EL brings back WILLOUGHBY's flowers and places them next to  BRANDON's on the side table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray sit down, Mr Willoughby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She indicates a chair but WILLOUGHBY sees a book lying on MARIANNE's footstool, picks it up and--to her great delig sits down on the stool at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is reading Shakespeare's sonnets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone answers at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. / We all are. / Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne has been reading them out  to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which are your favourites?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a general question but MARIANNE gaily commandeers i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a doubt, mine is 116.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me not to the marriage of true  minds Admit impediments. Love is not  love Which alters when it alteration  finds, Or bends with the remover to  remove--then how does it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: '0, no! it is an ever-fixed mark.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY joins in the line halfway through and continue ELINOR and MRS DASHWOOD exchange glances. Clearly, their  contribution to this conversation will be minimal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'That looks on storms'--or is it  tempests? Let me find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY gets out a tiny leatherbound book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is strange you should be reading  them--for, look, I carry this with  me always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a miniature copy of the sonnets. MARIANNE is deligh and, mutually astonished at this piece of synchronicity,  they proceed to look up other favourites, chatting as tho they were already intimates. MRS DASHWOOD smiles at ELINOR with satisfaction. ELINOR,  amused, picks up her sewing. MARGARET stares. WILLOUGHBY MARIANNE are oblivious to everything but each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY is leaving. He has a flower from MARIANNE's bu in his buttonhole and is on his horse, looking about as v as his horse. Everyone has come out to say goodbye, MARIA supported by ELINOR and MRS DASHWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till tomorrow! And my pocket sonnets  are yours, Miss Marianne! A talisman  against further injury!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye! Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gallops off. They all wave. MARGARET follows him down road for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work, Marianne! You have covered  all forms of poetry; another meeting  will ascertain his views on nature  and romantic attachments and then  you will have nothing left to talk  about and the acquaintanceship will  be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I have erred against  decorum. I should have been dull and  spiritless and talked only of the  weather, or the state of the roads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but Mr Willoughby can be in no  doubt of your enthusiasm for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should he doubt it? Why should I  hide my regard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No particular reason, Marianne, only  that we know so little of him--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But time alone does not determine  intimacy. Seven years would be  insufficient to make some people  acquainted with each other and seven  days are more than enough for others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or seven hours in this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel I know Mr Willoughby well  already. If I had weaker, more shallow  feelings perhaps I could conceal  them, as you do--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she realises what she's said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, that is not fair--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, Elinor, I did not mean

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Do not trouble yourself,  Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR turns back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not understand her, Mamma. Why  does she never mention Edward? I  have never even seen her cry about  him, or about Norland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I. But Elinor is not like you or  I, dear. She does not like to be  swayed by her emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on Edward's handkerchief. We can see the monogram E clearly. CLOSE on ELINOR staring out of the window. Tears stand in her eyes but she presses the handkerchief to them before  they fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner. Tea has been served. ELINOR, COLONEL BRANDO MRS DASHWOOD and MRS JENNINGS play at cards. In a far cor of the room, MARIANNE is concentrating as she draws a  silhouette. WILLOUGHBY's profile glows behind the screen in front of  her, She looks up and stops, gazing, bewitched, at his be The lips move--a whisper: Marianne. Then, louder: Haven't you finished? He moves out from behind the screen, eyes f of laughter. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MRS DASHWOOD are at the accounts. WILLOUGHBY a MARIANNE are on the other side of the room in the window  seat, whispering together. Clearly, he is already part of the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely you are not going to deny us  beef as well as sugar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nothing under tenpence a  pound. We have to economise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want us to starve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Just not to eat beef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD is silenced but sighs crossly. ELINOR looks  over to the lovers and sees WILLOUGHBY in the act of cutt off a lock of MARIANNE's hair, which he kisses and places his pocket-book. ELINOR is transfixed by this strangely e moment. WILLOUGHBY senses her gaze and looks over. She sn her head back to her sums and is astonished to find that has written 'Edward' at the top of the sheet. Hastily she rubs it out and writes 'Expenses'. EXT. BARTON CHURCH. DAY. MRS JENNINGS is talking to the elderly CURATE. Other  PARISHIONERS exit the church as WILLOUGHBY's curricle (th eighteenth-century equivalent of a sports car) goes flyin by. MARIANNE sits by his side, the picture of happiness. JENNINGS nudges the CURATE and whispers. The PARISHIONERS stare after them and comment to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE and ELINOR are coming down the path together.  MARIANNE is dressed to go out. The argument has evidently started indoors and is being continued here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there was any true impropriety in  my behaviour, I should be sensible  of it, Elinor--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as it has already exposed you to  some very impertinent remarks, do  you not begin to doubt your own  discretion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the impertinent remarks of such  as Mrs Jennings are proof of  impropriety, then we are all offending  every moment of our lives--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conversation is halted by the arrival of COLONEL BRAN on horseback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismounting) Miss Dashwood! Miss Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Colonel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come to issue an invitation. A  picnic on my estate at Delaford--if  you would care to join us on Thursday  next. Mrs Jennings's daughter and  her husband are traveling up  especially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Colonel, we shall be  delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, WILLOUGHBY's curricle hoves into view and MARIANNE's face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Marianne) I will of course be including Mr  Willoughby in the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even MARIANNE is a little embarrassed and recollects her  manners. She smiles kindly at BRANDON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be delighted to join you,  Colonel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COLONEL helps her into the curricle, exchanging nods  with WILLOUGHBY, who is regarding him with some suspicion

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Miss Dashwood; good  morning, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel has invited us to  Delaford, Willoughby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. I understand you have a  particularly fine pianoforte, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The undercurrents of this conversation are decidedly tens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Broadwood Grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Broadwood Grand! Then I shall really  be able to play for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall look forward to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE smiles her perfect happiness at him and he whips the horses. They drive off, waving their farewells. BRANDON looks after them for a silent moment, and then  collects himself and turns to ELINOR, who is less than  satisfied with their behaviour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister seems very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Marianne does not approve of  hiding her emotions. In fact, her  romantic prejudices have the  unfortunate tendency to set propriety  at naught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is wholly unspoilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather too unspoilt, in my view. The  sooner she becomes acquainted with  the ways of the world, the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLONEL BRANDON looks at her sharply and then speaks very deliberately, as though controlling some powerful emotion

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew a lady like your sister--the  same impulsive sweetness of temper-- who was forced into, as you put it,  a better acquaintance with the world.  The result was only ruination and  despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, and briskly remounts his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not desire it, Miss Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People and carriages fill the drive, the sun shines and t atmosphere is pleasantly expectant. SIR JOHN is organisin the provision of blankets and parasols and COLONEL BRANDO is busy furnishing the DRIVERS with their routes. There a three new faces a pretty, blowsy WOMAN (CHARLOTTE PALMER) stony-faced MAN (MR PALMER) and an exceedingly good-looki GIRL (LUCY STEELE), who are standing with ELINOR, MARIANN MARGARET, MRS JENNINGS and MRS DASHWOOD. MARIANNE is standing slightly apart, looking out along th road, impatient for WILLOUGHBY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine my surprise, Mrs Dashwood,  when Charlotte and her lord and master  appeared with our cousin Lucy! The  last person I expected to see! 'Where  did you pop out from, Miss?' says I.  I was never so surprised to see anyone  in all my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY STEELE smiles shyly and looks at the ground. MRS JEN continues sotto voce to MRS DASHWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She probably came on purpose to share  the fun, for there are no funds for  such luxuries at home, poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had not seen you for so long, dear  Mrs Jennings, I could not resist the  opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you sly thing! It was the Misses  Dashwood she wanted to see, not  Delaford, Mamma! I have heard nothing  but 'Miss Dashwood this, Miss Dashwood  that' for I don't know how long! And  what do you think of them now you do  see them, Lucy? My mother has talked  of nothing else in her letters since  you came to Barton, Mrs Dashwood. Mr  Palmer--are they not the very  creatures she describes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR PALMER regards his wife with a less than enchanted  expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing gaily) Why, Mr Palmer! Do you know you are  quite rude today? He is to be an MP,  you know, Mrs Dashwood, and it is  very fatiguing for him for he is  forced to make everybody like him-- he says it is quite shocking--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said anything so irrational.  Don't palm all your abuses of the  language upon me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs Dashwood) Mr Palmer is so droll--he is always  out of humour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR PALMER does indeed have the air of a man under siege.  WILLOUGH BY suddenly appears in his curricle. MARIANNE wa to him with a radiant smile. MRS JENNINGS nudges CHARLOTT and points to MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he is! Now you shall see,  Charlotte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY drives up as close to MARIANNE as possible, ma her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How now, Mr Willoughby! You must  greet my daughter Charlotte, and Mr  Palmer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my little cousin, Miss Lucy  Steele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to our party, Miss Steele!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY bobs demurely. WILLOUGHBY inclines his head politely leaps from the curricle and hands MARIANNE in. MRS JENNIN coos and chuckles at them. CHARLOTTE nudges ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Mr Willoughby extremely well-- not that I ever spoke to him but I  have seen him forever in town. Your  sister is monstrous lucky to get  him. Mamma says Colonel Brandon is  in love with her as well, which is a  very great compliment for he hardly  ever falls in love with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR smiles politely. WILLOUGHBY moves the curricle out the front of the drive. CHARLOTTE points after them and l with MRS JENNINGS. LUCY edges up beside ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I beg a seat beside you, Miss  Dashwood? I have so longed to make  your better acquaintance! I have  heard nothing but the highest praise  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is relieved to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be delighted. But Sir John  and Mrs Jennings are too excessive  in their compliments. I am sure to  disappoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, for it was from quite another  source that I heard you praised and  one not at all inclined to  exaggeration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY speaks in a knowing, confidential undertone, as thou not wanting anyone else to hear. At that moment a HORSEMA thunders up the drive towards them. Everyone turns to fac the new arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can this be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a MESSENGER who has obviously had a long, hard ride He asks for COLONEL BRANDON and hands him a letter, which BRANDON tears open. MRS JENNINGS is puce with suppressed  curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My horse! Quickly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the matter, Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must away to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Impossible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone gathers round BRANDON, who is, naturally, mortif A SERVANT brings up the COLONEL's horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imperative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a murmur of disappointment from the party. SIR J is embarrassed and protests again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Brandon, we are all assembled.  We cannot picnic at Delaford without  our host! Go up to town tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or wait till we return and start  then--you would not be six hours  later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot afford to lose one minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, he is mounting his horse. His grave urgency silences all protest and he gallops off, leaving everyone stunned and, of course, deeply curious. Then they all sta to talk at once. LUCY is still next to ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Dashwood, I cannot bear it!  Just when I was to have the  opportunity of speaking with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having been denied their trip, the DASHWOODS and WILLOUGH have set out an impromptu picnic. WILLOUGHBY is wandering restlessly about. The weather is sublime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frailty, thy name is Brandon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some people who cannot  bear a party of pleasure. I think he  wrote the letter himself as a trick  for getting out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indulgently) You are a very wicked pair, Colonel  Brandon will be sadly missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? When he is the kind of man that  everyone speaks well of and no one  wants to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon is very highly  esteemed at the Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is enough censure in itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half laughing) Really, Willoughby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Mrs Jennings  perfectly) Come, come, Mr Impudence--I know you  and your wicked ways--oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a little shriek and waddles about the garden doi her walk. He comes up to ELINOR and puts his head on her  shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Miss Dashwood, reveal your  beau, reveal him, I say! Let's have  no secrets between friends! Let me  winkle them out of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR hits him on the nose with her teaspoon and he wadd off to MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Mrs Jennings) I declare, Miss Marianne, if I do  not have you married to the Colonel  by teatime, I shall swallow my own  bonnet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE laughs. WILLOUGHBY drops the parody suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if you could marry such a  character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should you dislike him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is indeed an edge to WILLOUGHBY's raillery. He flic ELINOR an almost alarmed glance and then sweeps MARIANNE her feet and starts to dance around the garden with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he has threatened me with  rain when I wanted it fine, he has  found fault with the balance of my  curricle and I cannot persuade him  to buy my brown mare. If it will be  of any satisfaction to you, however,  to be told I believe his character  to be in all other respects  irreproachable, I am ready to confess  it. And in return for an  acknowledgement that must give me  some pain. (he is slowing down) You cannot deny me the privilege... (slower still) of disliking him... (and stopping) as much as I adore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and MARIANNE are standing looking at each other. The  expression on WILLOUGHBY's face is heart-stopping. MARGAR has stopped eating and is staring with her mouth open. ELINOR glances at MRS DASHWOOD but she is gazing up at th with almost as many stars in her eyes as MARIANNE. Suddenly WILLOUGHBY breaks the mood by swinging away from MARIANNE and gesturing to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --this cottage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tension is broken. MARGARET starts to chew again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have great plans for improvements  to it, you know, Mr Willoughby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that I will never consent to.  Not a stone must be added to its  walls. Were I rich enough, I would  instantly pull down Combe Magna and  build it up again in the exact image  of that cottage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With dark, narrow stairs, a poky  hall and a fire that smokes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially the fire that smokes!  Then I might be as happy at Combe  Magna as I have been at Barton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at MARIANNE, who has gone to sit at her mother's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this place has one claim on my  affection which no other can possibly  share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is so irradiated with happiness that she looks l an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you will never change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not have the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is seeing WILLOUGHBY off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Marianne, will you--will you do  me the honour of granting me an  interview tomorrow--alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby, we are always alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is something very particular  I should like to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something about his formal tone that makes her f shy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I shall ask Mamma if I  may stay behind from church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Until tomorrow then--Miss  Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mounts Bedivere and leaves. MARIANNE looks after him, eyes shining. He is coming to propose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A district of extreme poverty, populated by the LOWLIFE o LONDON: FOOTPADS, dogs, rats and SCAVENGERS of all kinds. the distance a tavern belches forth drunken REVELLERS who sway and reel into the night. A hooded HORSEMAN pulls up his exhausted steed at the ent to a slum. He dismounts and looks up at one of the window The rags hanging there twitch as if someone is watching f him. He strides inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stepping over a supine BEGGAR at the foot of the stairs, HORSEMAN flings back his hood--it is BRANDON, hollow-eyed and dropping with weariness. We follow him up the stairs a door which is opened by an OLDER WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters a bare room partitioned with filthy rags hung f the ceiling and lit with stinking tallow lamps. At the wi stands the slight figure of a VERY YOUNG WOMAN. She turns BRANDON reacts with a tender smile which stiffens into an expression of deep shock. We see her silhouette. She is  heavily pregnant. She bursts into tears and runs into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amongst the small CONGREGATION listening to the sermon dr on, we see the excited faces of ELINOR, MARGARET and MRS  DASHWOOD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he will kneel down when  he asks her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with satisfaction) They always kneel down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DASHWOODS return from church to find THOMAS grooming  Bedivere at the garden gate. Their excitement mounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all enter the cottage, talking nonsense loudly in or to signal their presence. MARGARET giggles. Suddenly, MAR bursts out of the parlour sobbing, and disappears into th room opposite. ELINOR and MARGARET stand by the door in u consternation, while MRS DASH- WOOD goes to MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong, my dearest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE shakes her head and waves them away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR, MARGARET and MRS DASHWOOD enter to find WILLOUGHB standing in a frozen attitude by the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby! What is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I--forgive me, Mrs Dashwood. I am  sent--that is to say, Lady Allen has  exercised the privilege of riches  upon a dependent cousin and is sending  me to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot look any of them in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When--this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost this moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How very disappointing! But your  business will not detain you from us  for long, I hope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very kind--but I have no  idea of returning immediately to  Devonshire. I am seldom invited to  Allenham more than once a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For shame, Willoughby! Can you wait  for an invitation from Barton Cottage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My engagements at present are of  such a nature--that is--I dare not  flatter myself--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is thick with tension. WILLOUGHBY flicks a glance at the three WOMEN staring at him in mute astonish

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is folly to linger in this manner.  I will not torment myself further.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes past them and out of the cottage. They follow h to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DASHWOODS cluster round the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby, come back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is silenced by ELINOR as WILLOUGHBY seizes Bedivere's reins from THOMAS, mounts up and rides off at a furious p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all rush back into the parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meg, dearest, please ask Betsy to  make a cup of hot tea for Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET nods dumbly and goes. MRS DASHWOOD has her arms  around MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong, my love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! Please do not ask me  questions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE struggles free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs off upstairs and we hear her bedroom door slammi There is a moment of stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have quarreled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is unlikely. Perhaps this--Lady  Allen--disapproves of his regard for  Marianne and has invented an excuse  to send him away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did he not say as much? It  is not like Willoughby to be  secretive. Did he think Marianne was  richer than she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures to the room and then looks at ELINOR with a  frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you suspect him of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly tell you. But why was  his manner so guilty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying, Elinor? That he  has been acting a part to your sister  for all this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD is getting defensive. ELINOR pauses to think

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he loves her, I am sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he loves her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But has he left her with any assurance  of his return? Cannot you ask her if  he has proposed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. I cannot force a  confidence from Marianne and nor  must you. We must trust her to confide  in us in her own time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) There was something so underhand in  the manner of his leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are resolved, then, to think the  worst of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not resolved--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) I prefer to give him the benefit of  my good opinion. He deserves no less.  From all of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stalks out of the room and starts up the stairs. ELIN follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma, I am very fond of Willoughby--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD goes into her bedroom and shuts the door. EL is halfway up the stairs. She meets a wet-eyed MARGARET c down with a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would not let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR takes the cup and MARGARET runs out into the garde in tears. The sound of sobbing also comes from MARIANNE's room, and now from MRS DASHWOOD's as well. ELINOR sits down helples on the stairs and drinks the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has settled in. The cottage looks cold and bleak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETSY carries another uneaten meal from MARIANNE's room. looks at the food and tuts in anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is sitting by the window looking out at the rain through tear-swollen eyes. WILLOUGHBY's sonnets are on he lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How like a winter hath my absence  been from thee, the pleasure of the  fleeting year! What freezings have I  felt, what dark days seen! What old  December's bareness everywhere!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke issues from every chimney in the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner is over. MARIANNE sits listlessly by the window. M PALMER is hiding behind a newspaper. SIR JOHN and MARGARE are looking at a map and discussing routes through China. LUCY, CHARLOTTE, MRS DASHWOOD and MRS JENNINGS are at car ELINOR is reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! If only this rain would stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from behind the paper) If only you would stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS and CHARLOTTE laugh at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Twas you took her off my hands, Mr  Palmer, and a very good bargain you  made of it too, but now I have the  whip hand over you for you cannot  give her back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heavy silence behind the paper attests to the unhappy truth of this statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Marianne, come and play a round  with us! Looking out at the weather  will not bring him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) She ate nothing at dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind, we are all a little forlorn  these days. London has swallowed all  our company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE and MRS JENNINGS start to gossip about the  disappearances of BRANDON and WILLOUGHBY. LUCY walks over and sits by ELINOR, who politely puts aside the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) Dear Miss Dashwood, perhaps now we  might have our--discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our discussion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY looks around at MRS JENNINGS and lowers her voice st further, so that ELINOR is obliged to move her chair near

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a particular question I  have long wanted to ask you, but  perhaps you will think me impertinent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot imagine so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is an odd question. Forgive  me, I have no wish to trouble you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks away coyly as if deciding whether to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Miss Steele--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Miss Dashwood, if only Mr Willoughby  had gone home to Combe Magna, we  could have taken Miss Marianne to  see him! For we live but half a mile  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I cannot believe it is that far,  for you can see the place from the  top of our hill. Is it really five  and a half miles? No! I cannot believe  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my permission to ask any  manner of question, if that is of  any help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I wonder, are you at all  acquainted with your sister-in-law's  mother? Mrs Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR sits back in deep surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Fanny's mother? No, I have never  met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure you think me strange for  inquiring--if I dared tell--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting over) If she tells you aught of the famous  'Mr F', Lucy, you are to pass it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR tries to ignore MRS JENNINGS, who is keeping a cur eye on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you take a turn with me, Miss  Dashwood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY rises and takes ELINOR's arm. She guides her as far  away as possible from MRS JENNINGS and CHARLOTTE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea at all that you were  connected with that family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! I am certainly nothing to Mrs  Ferrars at present--but the time may  come when we may be very intimately  connected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low) What do you mean? Do you have an  understanding with Fanny's brother  Robert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The youngest? No, I never saw him in  my life. No, with Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward and I have been secretly  engaged these five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is frozen to the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may well be surprised. I should  never have mentioned it, had I not  known I could entirely trust you to  keep our secret. Edward cannot mind  me telling you for he looks on you  quite as his own sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR walks on mechanically. Disbelief has set in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, but we surely--we cannot  mean the same Mr Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very same--he was four years  under the tutelage of my uncle Mr  Pratt, down in Plymouth. Has he never  spoken of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awareness dawning) Mr Pratt! Yes, I believe he has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was very unwilling to enter into  it without his mother's approval but  we loved each other with too great a  passion for prudence. Though you do  nor know him so well as I, Miss  Dashwood, you must have seen how  capable he is of making a woman  sincerely attached to him. I cannot  pretend it has not been very hard on  us both. We can hardly meet above  twice a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sniffs and produces a large handkerchief which she ho to her eyes so that the monogram is clearly visible. ECF. ELINOR, seeing the copy of the handkerchief she has held dear, moves quickly to a chair and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem out of sorts, Miss Dashwood-- are you quite well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have not offended you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS has been watching. Now she rises, unable to  contain herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can stand it no longer, I must  know what you are saying, Lucy! Miss  Dashwood is quite engrossed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS starts to bear down on them. LUCY whispers w real urgency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Miss Dashwood, if anyone finds  out, it will ruin him--you must not  tell a soul! Edward says you would  not break your word to save your  life! Promise me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ECU on ELINOR's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS looms over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what can have fascinated you  to such an extent, Miss Dashwood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR cannot speak but LUCY glides smoothly in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were talking of London, ma'am,  and all its--diversions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hear, Charlotte?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS claps her hands delightedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you were so busy whispering,  Charlotte and I have concocted a  plan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the best plan in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make for London shortly and I invite  you, Lucy, and both the Misses  Dashwood to join me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR cannot hide her dismay. MARIANNE springs from her  seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: London!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, can I go! Can I go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know perfectly well you are too  young, dearest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall convey you all to my house  in Berkeley Street and we shall taste  all the delights of the season--what  say you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please can I go? I'm twelve soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Palmer, do you not long to have  the Misses Dashwood come to London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came into Devonshire with no other  view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR exerts herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Jennings, you are very kind, but  we cannot possibly leave our mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY's calculating eyes turn to MRS DASHWOOD with alacrit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, the loss would be too great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chorus of objections goes up, particularly from MRS  DASHWOOD, who is both delighted and relieved to see MARIA with a smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother can spare you very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she can!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look at Miss Marianne--it would  break her heart to deny her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will brook no refusal, Miss  Dashwood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE claps her hands, her eyes ablaze with joy. MRS  JENNINGS takes ELINOR's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let you and me strike hands upon the  bargain--and if I do not have the  three of you married by Christmas,  it will not be my fault!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in ELINOR and MARIANNE's bedroom. ELINOR is in bed She is lying on her side with her back to MARIANNE. We ar CLOSE on her face. MARIANNE is running around excitedly,  pulling out ribbons, looking at dresses, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never so grateful in all my  life as I am to Mrs Jennings. What a  kind woman she is! I like her more  than I can say. Oh, Elinor! I shall  see Willoughby. Think how surprised  he will be! And you will see Edward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR cannot reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With you in the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not believe you feel as calm as  you look, not even you, Elinor. I  will never sleep tonight! Oh, what  were you and Miss Steele whispering  about so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on ELINOR's expression as she struggles with the  impossibility of unburdening herself to her sister withou breaking her promise to LUCY. After a pause--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing of significance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks at ELINOR curiously, then returns to her  packing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD and MARGARET are waving MRS JENNINGS's carri off. MARIANNE waves back with such exuberance that she  practically falls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS is chattering about London to MARIANNE, who  listens with new-found tolerance. LUCY is whispering into ELINOR's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have written to Edward, Miss  Dashwood, and yet I do not know how  much I may see of him. Secrecy is  vital--he will never be able to call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should imagine not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is so hard. I believe my only  comfort has been the constancy of  his affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are fortunate, over such a lengthy  engagement, never to have had any  doubts on that score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY looks at ELINOR sharply, but ELINOR is impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! I am of rather a jealous nature  and if he had talked more of one  young lady than any other... but he  has never given a moment's alarm on  that count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see from ELINOR's expression that she understands  LUCY perfectly. The strain around her eyes is pronounced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine how glad he will be to learn  that we are friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS's carriage trundles along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of a handsome town house. MRS JENNINGS' carriage comes into shot and stops in front of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the grand hallway under the supercilious gaze a powdered FOOTMAN (MR PIGEON). ELINOR is haggard after t days of close proximity with LUCY. MRS JENNINGS is all  officious bustle and MARIANNE is feverish with anticipati She whispers to MRS JENNINGS, who laughs heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be sure, my dear, you must just  hand it to Pigeon there. He will  take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE hands a letter to the sphinx-like FOOTMAN. We ca see a large W in the address. ELINOR looks at MARIANNE  inquiringly but MARIANNE moves away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord above, you do not waste any  time, Miss Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE glances self-consciously at ELINOR and follows M JENNINGS upstairs. LUCY goes up to ELINOR and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter! So they are definitely  engaged! Mrs Jennings says your sister  will buy her wedding clothes here in  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed Miss Steele, I know of no  such plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But ELINOR does not know what else to say. She marches fi upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE and ELINOR have changed from their traveling clo and are having a cup of tea. At least, ELINOR is. MARIANN is pacing up and down in front of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John and Fanny are in town. I think  we shall be forced to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a faint knocking from somewhere. MARIANNE jumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was for next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down with a rueful smile. Suddenly a much louder rap is heard and they both jump. We hear a bustling  downstairs. MARIANNE can hardly breathe. She goes to the  drawing-room door, opens it, goes out, comes back in. We  hear a MAN's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Elinor! It is Willoughby, indeed  it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and almost throws herself into the arms of COLO BRANDON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Excuse me, Colonel--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the room hastily. ELINOR is so ashamed of  MARIANNE's rudeness that she does not at first notice  BRANDON's mood of tense distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon, what a pleasure to  see you! Have you been in London all  this while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have. How is your dear mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, is there anything--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But BRANDON interrupts her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Miss Dashwood, but I  have heard reports through town...  is it impossible to--but I could  have no chance of succeeding--indeed  I hardly know what to do. Tell me  once and for all, is everything  finally resolved between your sister  and Mr Willoughby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is torn between discomfiture and compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, though neither one has  informed me of their under standing,  I have no doubt of their mutual  affection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON stands very still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Dashwood. To your  sister I wish all imaginable  happiness. To Mr Willoughby, that  he... may endeavour to deserve her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His tone is heavy with some bitter meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he recollects himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I--forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows and leaves abruptly. ELINOR is deeply troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PALMERS, MRS JENNINGS, JOHN, FANNY, LUCY, ELINOR and  MARIANNE are walking through the arcade. Additional wealt has evidently encouraged FANNY sartorially and she sprout as much fruit and feathers as a market stall. LUCY is hol ELINOR's arm in a pinionlike grip. MRS JENNINGS is gossip with CHARLOTTE. MARIANNE's good looks are heightened by her feverish  expectation of seeing WILLOUGHBY at every step, and many  young men raise their hats to her and turn as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is dear Edward, John? We expect  to see him daily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY stiffens. LUCY's sharp eyes dart hither and thither MRS JENNINGS senses gossip. ELINOR steels herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who is 'dear Edward'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY smiles glacially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother, Mrs Jennings--Edward  Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS looks at ELINOR in sly triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed! Is that Ferrars with an F?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and CHARLOTTE chuckle to each other. LUCY looks at EL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS, LUCY, ELINOR and MARIANNE return from their outing. MARIANNE immediately assails PIGEON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any messages, Pigeon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No message at all? No cards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affronted) None, ma am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE sighs with disappointment and starts up the stai MRS JENNINGS looks archly at ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I note you do not inquire for your  messages, Miss Dashwood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, for I do not expect any, Mrs  Jennings. I have very little  acquaintance in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she follows MARIANNE firmly upstairs. LUCY watches he go, and MRS JENNINGS chuckles and turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is as sly as you, Lucy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR wakes up. The flickering of a candle has disturbed her. She sits up in bed and sees MARIANNE sitting at the  desk in her nightgown, writing another letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, is anything wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing at all. Go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE, in her nightclothes and dressing gown, paces  restlessly, her letter in her hands. A slight knock at th door heralds a much-ruffled PIGEON, wig askew. MARIANNE h him the letter. He bows and goes, highly disgruntled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS is giving PIGEON his instructions for the da MARIANNE comes running downstairs. PIGEON regards her dri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No messages, ma am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks so dejected that MRS JENNINGS takes her ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not fret, my dear. I am told that  this good weather is keeping many  sportsmen in the country at present,  but the frost will drive them back  to town very soon, depend upon it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! I had not thought of-- thank you, Mrs Jennings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs back upstairs. MRS JENNINGS calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Miss Dashwood may set her heart  at rest, for I overheard your sister- in-law say that she was to bring the  elusive Mr F to the ball tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So many carriages have entered the crescent to deliver th GUESTS that gridlock has occurred and people are forced t walk to the entrance. We see MRS JENNINGS, MARIANNE, ELIN and LUCY alighting from their carriage and picking their through the mud, their skirts raised above their ankles.  ELINOR nearly trips and is obliged to grab onto LUCY in o not to slip into the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great ballroom is crammed with GUESTS all determined enjoy themselves despite the considerable inconveniences  caused by noise, heat and overcrowding. MEN are sweating  profusely, WOMEN dab their brows, rack punch is being  swallowed by the gallon, flirting is conducted at fever p and all conversation is inordinately loud. Only the DANCE have a modicum of space in which to perform their mincing steps. MRS JENNINGS and her brood bump into the PALMERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screeching) This is very merry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS then spots FANNY, who is conducting a desult conversation with an overpowdered ACQUAINTANCE. She drags ELINOR, MARIANNE and LUCY over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are! Goodness, how hot it  is, Mrs Dashwood. You are not alone,  I trust?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed not. John is just gone to  fetch my brother--he has been eating  ices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY clutches at ELINOR's sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother! I declare, that is  good news indeed. At long last!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she beams her approval upon ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Miss Dashwood, I declare I shall  faint clean away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY has seen JOHN threading his way towards them and wa at him. There is someone behind him. LUCY preens. JOHN bo to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Jennings, may I present my brother- in-law?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to reveal a good-looking young MAN with a vacuou smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Robert Ferrars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear ladies--we meet at last!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general bowing and shaking of hands. ELINOR is relieved. LUCY drops a low curtsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you must be the younger brother?  Is Mr Edward not here? Miss Dashwood  here was counting on him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT looks ELINOR up and down. He exchanges glances wit FANNY before he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! He is far too busy for such  gatherings--and has no special  acquaintance here to make his  attendance worthwhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS looks at ELINOR in puzzlement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I declare, I do not know what  the young men are about these days-- are they all in hiding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks down, agonised with embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Mr Robert, in the absence of  your brother, you must dance with  our lovely Miss Dashwood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not best pleased) It would be my honour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to LUCY and bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And perhaps Miss Steele might consider  reserving the allemande?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY curtsies again. ROBERT escorts a most unwilling ELIN onto the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You reside in Devonshire, I b'lieve,  Miss Dashwood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a cottage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am excessively fond of a cottage.  If I had any money to spare, I should  build one myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luckily for ELINOR the set changes and she is obliged to  turn away from ROBERT. She wheels round to face her new  partner. It is WILLOUGHBY! They both stop dancing and sta at each other aghast. A traffic jam starts and they are f to take hands and resume the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiff) How do you do, Miss Dashwood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR does not know quite how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am well, thank you, Mr Willoughby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks about for MARIANNE, instinctively wanting to ke her away from WILLOUGHBY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your--family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) We are all extremely well, Mr  Willoughby--thank you for your kind  inquiry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY is shamed into silence. Then he sees MARIANNE. the same moment the music pauses. MARIANNE looks up. In t brief moment of relative quiet, her great cry rings acros the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone turns to look as MARIANNE rushes towards him wit both arms outstretched, her face luminous with joy. As th noise of the room builds again and PEOPLE change their  partners, we are aware that many are surreptitiously watc MARIANNE reaches him but WILLOUGHBY stands with his arms  frozen at his side. MARIANNE gives a little confused laug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God, Willoughby! Will you nor  shake hands with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY looks extremely uncomfortable and glances towa a group of very smart PEOPLE who are watching him closely Central to this group is a SOPHISTICATED WOMAN who frowns him proprietorially. WILLOUGHBY shakes MARIANNE's hand briefly. Behind her, MR JENNINGS is giving an animated commentary to FANNY and JO while LUCY whispers in ROBERT's ear as they go past to jo the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strangled) How do you do, Miss Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby, what is the matter? Why  have you not come to see me? Were  you not in London? Have you nor  received my letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLOUGHBY is sweating with tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I had the pleasure of receiving  the information which you were so  good as to send me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (piteously) For heaven's sake, Willoughby, tell  me what is wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you--I am most obliged. If you  will excuse me, I must return to my  party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows, white to the teeth, and walks away to join the  SOPHISTICATED WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is drawn away by his PARTY, some of whom look back at  MARIANNE with a mixture of curiosity and condescension.  MARIANNE almost sinks to her knees. ELINOR supports her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne! Come away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to him, Elinor--force him to come  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS has come up, full of concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest, do not betray what you feel  to everyone present! This is not the  place for explanations--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They almost have to drag MARIANNE away. MRS JENNINGS turn back to the DASHWOOD party. FANNY and JOHN have practical imploded with embarrassment and are distancing themselves much as possible from the source. LUCY and ROBERT are dan nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you come, Lucy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, are we leaving so soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I might be so bold, Mrs Jennings,  it would be our pleasure to escort  your young charge home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How very kind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is very handsome--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes off to follow MARIANNE and ELINOR. We stay for moment with LUCY and ROBERT who have left the set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She actually sent him messages during  the night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAM rises to show the DASHWOODS exiting past the whisperi sneering faces of the CROWD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE sits scribbling a letter at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, please tell me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not ask me questions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no confidence in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This reproach from you! You, who  confide in no one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have nothing to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor I. We have neither of us anything  to tell. I because I conceal nothing  and you because you communicate  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent breakfast. MARIANNE is red-eyed from crying and  limp from lack of sleep. MRS JENNINGS is dressed to go ou pulling on her gloves and bustling as usual. PIGEON enter with a letter on a salver. He offers it to MARIANNE. She  seizes it and runs out of the room. MRS JENNINGS chuckles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There now! Lovers' quarrels are swift  to heal! That letter will do the  trick, mark my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be off. I hope he won't keep  her waiting much longer, Miss  Dashwood. It hurts to see her looking  so forlorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves and ELINOR finds herself alone with LUCY, who  loses no time in sharing her new-found happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a welcome I had from Edward's  family, Miss Dashwood--I am surprised  you never told me what an agreeable  woman your sister-in-law is! And Mr  Robert--all so affable!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is perhaps fortunate that none of  them knows of your engagement. Excuse  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR rises and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR finds MARIANNE sitting on the edge of the bed. She does not acknowledge ELINOR but merely lifts the letter a reads out, with deadly calm:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'My dear Madam--I am quite at a loss  to discover in what point I could be  so unfortunate as to offend you. My  esteem for your family is very sincere  but if I have given rise to a belief  of more than I felt or meant to  express, I shall reproach myself for  not having been more guarded. My  affections have long been engaged  elsewhere and it is with great regret  that I return your letters and the  lock of hair which you so obligingly  bestowed upon me. I am etc. John  Willoughby.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE gives a great howl of pain and flings herself ac the bed as though in physical agony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, oh, Marianne--it is better  to know at once what his intentions  are. Dearest, think of what you would  have felt if your engagement had  carried on for months and months  before he chose to put an end to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you wrote to him! I thought then  that he must have left you with some  kind of understanding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--he is not so unworthy as you  think him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so unworthy! Did he tell you  that he loved you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. No--never absolutely. It was  every day implied, but never declared.  Sometimes I thought it had been, but  it never was. He has broken no vow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has broken faith with all of us,  he made us all believe he loved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did! He did--he loved me as I  loved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS bursts through the door in her hat and coat, panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to come straight up--how are  you, Miss Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE begins to sob uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor thing! She looks very bad. No  wonder, Miss Dashwood, for it is but  too true. I was told here in the  street by Miss Morton, who is a great  friend: he is to be married at the  end of the month--to a Miss Grey  with fifty thousand pounds. Well,  said I, if 'tis true, then he is a  good-for-nothing who has used my  young friend abominably ill, and I  wish with all my soul that his wife  may plague his heart out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes round the bed to comfort MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he is not the only young man  worth having, my dear, and with your  pretty face you will never want for  admirers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE sobs even harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, me! She had better have her cry  out and have done with it. I will go  and look out something to tempt her-- does she care for olives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS leaves. MARIANNE seizes the letter again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot believe his nature capable  of such cruelty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, there is no excuse for him-- this is his hand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it cannot be his heart! Oh, Mamma!  I want Mamma! Elinor, please take me  home! Cannot we go tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no one to take us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cannot we hire a carriage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no money--and indeed we owe  Mrs Jennings more courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All she wants is gossip and she only  likes me because I supply it! Oh,  God! I cannot endure to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will find a way. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY, JOHN and ROBERT are drinking chocolate together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently they never were engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Grey has fifty thousand pounds.  Marianne is virtually penniless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cannot have expected him to go  through with it. But I feel for  Marianne--she will lose her bloom  and end a spinster like Elinor. I  think, my dear, we might consider  having them to stay with us for a  few days--we are, after all, family,  and my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He trails off. FANNY exchanges an alarmed glance with ROB She thinks fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My love, I would ask them with all  my heart, but I have already asked  Miss Steele for a visit and we cannot  deprive Mrs Jennings of all her  company at once. We can invite your  sisters some other year, you know,  and Miss Steele will profit far more  from your generosity--poor girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is very thoughtful, Fanny. We  shall ask Elinor and Marianne next  year, then... Certainly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS's carriage stands outside. A livened FOOTMAN opens the door and LUCY steps out brandishing a new muff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE sits alone on the bed. Around her lie her notes Willoughby, her lock of hair and the pocket sonnets. In h hands is the creased and tear-stained letter from Willoug which she is examining over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is seated at a desk writing a letter. There is a s rap at the front door. Footsteps are heard and as she tur the maid enters with COLONEL BRANDON. ELINOR rises to gre him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows. ELINOR is on edge. BRANDON looks haggard with  concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must get her home as quickly as  possible. The Palmers can take us as  far as Cleveland, which is but a day  from Barton--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then permit me to accompany you and  take you straight on from Cleveland  to Barton myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR takes his hands gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I confess that is precisely what I  had hoped for. Marianne suffers  cruelly, and what pains me most is  how hard she tries to justify Mr  Willoughby. But you know her  disposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment BRANDON nods. He seems unable to remain st or calm and finds it difficult to begin speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps I--my regard for you all-- Miss Dashwood, will you allow me to  prove it by relating some  circumstances which nothing but an  earnest desire of being useful--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have something to tell me of Mr  Willoughby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) When I quitted Barton last--but I  must go further back. A short account  of myself will be necessary. No  doubt... no doubt Mrs Jennings has  apprised you of certain events in my  past--the sad outcome of my connection  with a young woman named Eliza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is not commonly known is that  twenty years ago, Eliza bore an  illegitimate child. The father,  whoever he was, abandoned them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is strong stuff. ELINOR's concern deepens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she lay dying, she begged me to  look after the child. Eliza died in  my arms, broken, wasted away--ah!  Miss Dashwood, such a subject-- untouched for so many years--it is  dangerous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He paces about, barely able to conceal his distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had failed Eliza in every other  way--I could not refuse her now. I  took the child--Beth is her name-- and placed her with a family where I  could be sure she would be well looked  after. I saw her whenever I could. I  saw that she was headstrong like her  mother--and, God forgive me, I  indulged her, I allowed her too much  freedom. Almost a year ago, she  disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappeared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I instigated a search but for eight  months I was left to imagine the  worst. At last, on the day of the  Delaford picnic, I received the first  news her. She was with child... and  the blackguard who had--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON stops and looks straight at ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God. Do you mean--Willoughby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON nods. ELINOR drops into a chair, utterly shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I could return to confront  him, Lady Allen learned of his  behaviour and turned him from the  house. He beat a hasty retreat to  London--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! He left us that morning, without  any explanation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Allen had annulled his legacy.  He was left with next to nothing,  and in danger of losing all that  remained to his debtors--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --and so abandoned Marianne for Miss  Grey and her fifty thousand pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON is silent. ELINOR is breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Mr Willoughby since  you learned...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) We met by appointment, he to defend,  I to punish his conduct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR stares at him, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We returned unwounded, so the meeting  never got abroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR nods and is silent for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Beth still in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has chosen to go into the country  for her confinement. Such has been  the unhappy resemblance between the  fate of mother and daughter, and so  imperfectly have I discharged my  trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would not have burdened you, Miss  Dashwood, had I not from my heart  believed it might, in time, lessen  your sister's regrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON moves to the door and then stops. He turns to her and speaks with effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have described Mr Willoughby as  the worst of libertines--but I have  since learned from Lady Allen that  he did mean to propose that day.  Therefore I cannot deny that his  intentions towards Marianne were  honourable, and I feel certain he  would have married her, had it not  been for--for the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up at BRANDON. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is sitting on the bed staring into space. ELINOR kneeling by her, holding her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest, was I right to tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever his past actions, whatever  his present course, at least you may  be certain that he loved you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not enough. Not enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR sits alone with her head in her hands. Suddenly MR JENNINGS hustles in looking pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is someone to cheer you up,  Miss Dashwood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is followed in by LUCY. MRS JENNINGS leaves, busy as  ever. LUCY plants an expression of ghastly concern on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is your dear sister, Miss  Dashwood? Poor thing! I must say, I  do not know what I should do if a  man treated me with so little respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you are enjoying your stay  with John and Fanny, Miss Steele?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was never so happy in my entire  life, Miss Dashwood! I do believe  your sister-in-law has taken quite a  fancy to me. I had to come and tell  you--for you cannot imagine what has  happened!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday I was introduced to Edward's  mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed?
