dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she was a vast deal more than  civil. I have not yet seen Edward  but now I feel sure to very soon--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAID comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a Mr Edward Ferrars to see  you, Miss Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a tiny frozen silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do ask him to come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR quite involuntarily sits down and then stands up a EDWARD is admitted, looking both anxious and eager. As LU is sitting in the window seat, at first he sees only ELIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Dashwood, how can I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But ELINOR cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ferrars, what a pleasure to see  you. You... know Miss Steele, of  course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD turns slowly and encounters LUCY's glassy smile. H all but blanches. Then bows, and clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Miss Steele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am well, thank you, Mr Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD has no notion of what to do or say. He swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do sit down, Mr Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY's eyes are sharp as broken glass. EDWARD remains on feet, looking helplessly from one woman to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be surprised to find me  here, Mr Ferrars! I expect you thought  I was at your sister's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is precisely what EDWARD had thought. He tries to sm but his facial muscles won't work. ELINOR decides to fetc help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me call Marianne, Mr Ferrars.  She would be most disappointed to  miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR goes to the door, thankful to escape, but MARIANNE prevents her by walking in at that moment. Despite her  anguish, she is very pleased to see EDWARD and embraces h warmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward! I heard your voice! At last  you have found us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD is shocked by her appearance and momentarily forge his own confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Marianne, my visit is  shamefully overdue. You are pale. I  hope you have not been unwell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't think of me--Elinor is  well, you see, that must be enough  for both of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE gestures to ELINOR encouragingly but EDWARD seem unable to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like London, Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. The sight of you is all  the pleasure it has afforded, is  that not so, Elinor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, MARIANNE endeavours to ignite the lovers. ELINOR t to silence MARIANNE with her eyes but to no avail. MARIAN puts their coolness down to the presence of LUCY, at whom she glances with a none too friendly air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why have you taken so long to come  and see us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been much engaged elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaged elsewhere! But what was that  when there were such friends to be  met?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps, Miss Marianne, you think  young men never honour their  engagements, little or great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is appalled by this remark but MARIANNE does not n it and turns back to LUCY earnestly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, indeed--for Edward is the most  fearful of giving pain and the most  incapable of being selfish of anyone  I ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD makes an uncomfortable noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward, will you not sit? Elinor,  help me to persuade him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now EDWARD can stand it no longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me but I must take my leave--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are only just arrived!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR rises, desperate for them both to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must excuse me, I have a  commission to attend to for Fanny--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY jumps in like a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case perhaps you might escort  me back to your sister's house, Mr  Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is an extremely awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be honoured. Goodbye, Miss  Dashwood, Miss Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes hands with ELINOR and with MARIANNE, who is sil with dismay. LUCY takes EDWARD's arm and looks up at him  proprietorially. After a stiff bow and a muttered farewell from EDWARD, th leave. MARIANNE looks at her sister in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not urge him to stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have had his reasons for  going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His reason was no doubt your coldness.  If I were Edward I would assume you  did not care for me at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tranquil afternoon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY is sitting with FANNY, who is doing some pointless  basketwork. LUCY hands FANNY rushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Miss Marianne looked very badly  t'other day. When I think of her,  deserted and abandoned, it frightens  me to think I shall never marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You will marry far better  than either of the Dashwood girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can that possibly be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have ten times their sense and  looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I have no dowry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are qualities which will always  make up for that, and you have them  in abundance. It would not surprise  me if you were to marry far and away  beyond your expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it might be so. There is a  young man--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah ha! I am glad to hear of it. Is  he of good breeding and fortune?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh both--but his family would  certainly oppose the match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tush! They will allow it as soon as  they see you, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a very great secret. I have  told no one in the world for fear of  discovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY looks up, curious to know more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, I am the soul of discretion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I dared tell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you I am as silent as  the grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY leans forward to whisper in FANNY's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold a long shot of the house for a moment of silence. Then from inside comes an almost inhumanly loud shriek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Viper in my bosom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANNY is trying to drag LUCY out of the house. ROBERT and JOHN are trying to reason with her. FANNY loses her grip falls backwards. LUCY flings herself into ROBERT's arms.  ROBERT falls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS is running as fast as her fat little legs wi carry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS JENNINGS pants up the front steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MARIANNE are packing. Their mood is gloomy and uncommunicative. MRS JENNINGS explodes into the room figh for breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my dears! What a commotion! Mr  Edward Ferrars--the very one I used  to joke you about, Miss Dashwood-- has been engaged these five years to  Lucy Steele!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE lets out a gasp. She looks at ELINOR, who nods a her in swift confirmation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Mr Ferrars! His mother, who by  all accounts is very proud, demanded  that he break the engagement on pain  of disinheritance. But he has refused  to break his promise to Lucy. He has  stood by her, good man, and is cut  off without a penny! She has settled  it all irrevocably upon Mr Robert.  But I cannot stop, I must go to Lucy.  Your sister-in-law scolded her like  any fury--drove her to hysterics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves the room, still rabbiting on. There is a silen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you known?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since the evening Mrs Jennings offered  to take us to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy told me in the strictest  confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks at her in complete incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could not break my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearly, there is no arguing this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Edward loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made me no promises. He tried to  tell me about Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot marry her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have him treat her even  worse than Willoughby has treated  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--but nor would I have him marry  where he does not love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR tries hard to be controlled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward made his promise a long time  ago, long before he met me. Though  he may... harbour some regret, I  believe he will be happy--in the  knowledge that he did his duty and  kept his word. After all--after all  that is bewitching in the idea of  one's happiness depending entirely  on one person, it is not always  possible. We must accept. Edward  will marry Lucy--and you and I will  go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always resignation and acceptance!  Always prudence and honour and duty!  Elinor, where is your heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR finally explodes. She turns upon MARIANNE almost  savagely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know of my heart? What  do you know of anything but your own  suffering? For weeks, Marianne, I  have had this pressing on me without  being at liberty to speak of it to a  single creature. It was forced upon  me by the very person whose prior  claims ruined all my hopes. I have  had to endure her exultation again  and again while knowing myself to be  divided from Edward forever. Believe  me, Marianne, had I not been bound  to silence I could have produced  proof enough of a broken heart even  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Complete silence. Then MARIANNE speaks in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Elinor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE bursts into sobs and flings her arms around ELIN who, almost impatiently, tries to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY and MRS JENNINGS are on the doorstep. LUCY looks rat lost and pathetic, with her little bundles, hastily packe The door opens and CHARLOTTE precedes the SERVANT, usheri them in with shrill cries of sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard that your friend Mr  Ferrars has been entirely cast off  by his family for persevering in his  engagement to Miss Steele.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and BRANDON walk round the quiet square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I been rightly informed? Is it  so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is greatly taken aback by this unexpected query.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is indeed so. Are you acquainted  with Mr Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we have never met. But I know  only too well the cruelty--the  impolitic cruelty of dividing two  young people long attached to one  another. Mrs Ferrars does not know  what she may drive her son to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, frowning in remembrance. ELINOR waits in suspe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a proposal to make that should  enable him to marry Miss Steele  immediately. Since the gentleman is  so close a friend to your family,  perhaps you will be good enough to  mention it to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is completely taken aback. She takes a moment to r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I am sure he would be only  too delighted to hear it from your  own lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think not. His behaviour has proved  him proud--in the best sense. I feel  certain this is the right course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is waiting. The MAID announces EDWARD and he walks momentarily. They are alone for the first time in months for a moment, neither speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR indicates a seat for him but neither sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for responding so promptly  to my message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was most grateful to receive it. I-- Miss Dashwood, God knows what you  must think of me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ferrars--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He interrupts her, desperate to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no right to speak, I know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR has to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ferrars, I have good news. I think  you know of our friend Colonel  Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD looks completely bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have heard his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR starts to speak rather faster than usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon desires me to say  that, understanding you wish to join  the clergy, he has great pleasure in  offering you the parish on his estate  at Delaford, now just vacant, in the  hope that it may enable you--and  Miss Steele--to marry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD cannot at first take it in. ELINOR sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He means it as testimony of his  concern for--for the cruel situation  in which you find yourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now EDWARD sits--in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon give me a parish?  Can it be possible?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The unkindness of your family has  made you astonished to find friendship  elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD looks at ELINOR, his eyes full of growing  comprehension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not to find it in you. I cannot  be ignorant that to you--to your  goodness--I owe it all. I feel it. I  would express it if I could, but, as  you know, I am no orator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are very much mistaken. I assure  you that you owe it almost entirely  to your own merit--I have had no  hand in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But EDWARD clearly believes she has been instrumental in offer. He frowns slightly before speaking with rather an  effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon must be a man of  great worth and respect ability.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR finds some relief in saying at least one thing tha she truly means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is the kindest and best of men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This makes EDWARD seem even more depressed. He sits silen for a moment but then rouses himself to action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I enquire why the Colonel did  not tell me himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he felt it would be better  coming from... a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD looks at ELINOR, his eyes full of sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your friendship has been the most  important of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will always have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ferrars, you honour your promises-- that is more important than anything  else. I wish you--both--very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rise. She curtsies. He bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Miss Dashwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD leaves silently. ELINOR stands stock-still in the  middle of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PALMERS' carriage stands outside the house. COLONEL  BRANDON helps MARIANNE in beside ELINOR before mounting h horse to ride alongside. MRS JENNINGS waves goodbye from steps. The carriage moves off. MRS JENNINGS blows her nos looks up and down the street in search of gossip and goes back indoors with a sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is sitting back in her seat with her eyes closed She does not look well. MR PALMER is behind his newspaper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a stroke of luck for Lucy and  Edward to find a parish so close to  Barton! You will all be able to meet  very often. That will cheer you up,  Miss Marianne. I do declare I have  never disliked a person so much as I  do Mr Willoughby, for your sake.  Insufferable man! To think we can  see his insufferable house from the  top of our hill!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on MARIANNE's eyes slowly opening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall ask Jackson to plant some  very tall trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from behind the paper) You will do nothing of the sort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage bowls along, with BRANDON riding next to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear Miss Grey's bridal gown was  everything of the finest--made in  Paris, no less. I should have liked  to see it, although I dare say it  was a sorry affair, scalloped with  ruffles--but what do the French know  about fashion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage stands outside the PALMER residence, a  resplendent affair with a great deal of land. BRANDON is  helping MARIANNE and ELINOR out of the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am resolved never to mention Mr  Willoughby's name again, and  furthermore I shall tell everyone I  meet what a good-for nothing he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MARIANNE stand on the steps as the PALMERS deb from the carriage amid a welter of SERVANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce) I do not think she drew breath from  the moment we left London. It is my  fault--I should have found some other  way of getting home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no other way you said so  yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall be home soon enough. Mamma  will comfort you, dearest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am stiff from sitting so long.  Will you tell Charlotte that I am  going for a stroll? ELINOR glances  at the sky in concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is going to rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it will not rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR cannot help but smile at this return of the old  MARIANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always say that and then it always  does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will keep to the garden, near the  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE walks off. ELINOR watches her go anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS BUNTING, a rather baleful NANNY, looks on as MR PALME holds up a screaming BABY in a frilly bonnet for everyone inspection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are very proud of our little  Thomas, Colonel--and his papa has  such a way with him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON flicks a glance at MR PALMER for whom holding a b comes as naturally as breathing underwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE walks purposefully towards the garden wall, beyo which lies a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR enters to find CHARLOTTE alone with the now hyster BABY THOMAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, Miss Dashwood! Mr  Palmer and the Colonel have locked  themselves up in the billiard room.  Come and meet little Thomas. Where  is Miss Marianne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is taking a little air in the  garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, very good. That is the great  advantage of the countryside--all  the fresh air and... and all the  fresh air...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE's conversational difficulties are drowned out b her offspring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE comes to a gate in the wall and turns the handle It opens. She throws a glance back to the house and passe through. There is a low rumble of thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BABY THOMAS is purple in the face but shows no signs of  quietening. CHARLOTTE joggles him about inefficiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) He is the best child in the world-- he never cries unless he wants to  and then, Lord, there is no stopping  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE, calm and determined, walks towards the top of t hill. The wind whips and plucks at her hair and skirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR, traumatised by her new acquaintance with the shri BABY THOMAS, goes to look out of the window. She frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR's POV. MARIANNE is nowhere in sight. Storm clouds  have gathered on the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR turns from the window. BABY THOMAS stops crying fo two seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot see Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a crack of thunder. BABY THOMAS starts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain has started to pour down. MARIANNE walks on regardle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE shouts over BABY THOMAS to ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has probably taken shelter in  one of the greenhouses!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE has reached the top. Soaked to the skin, she sta with the storm raging around her, staring at the spires o Combe Magna, the place that would have been her home. Rai streaks her face and the wind whips her hair about her.  Through frozen lips she whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love is not love Which alters when  it alteration finds Or bends with  the remover to remove: 0, no! it is  an ever-fixed mark That looks on  tempests and is never shaken...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON is looking for MARIANNE. He enters a greenhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE stares at Combe Magna, a strange smile playing a her lips. Then she calls to WILLOUGHBY as though he were  near. The effect is eerie, unworldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willoughby... Willoughby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE, MR PALMER and ELINOR are waiting anxiously. BA THOMAS has been removed. ELINOR is staring out of the win

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing is certain--she will be  wet through when she returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for pointing that out, my  dear. Do not worry, Miss Dashwood-- Brandon will find her. I think we  can all guess where she went.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON runs up the hillside as though the devil were at heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE is handing ELINOR a cup of tea. ELINOR turns ba to look out of the window. She freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR's POV of BRANDON walking up to the house with MARI cradled in his arms. It is like seeing Willoughby's ghost

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone rushes out of the drawing room as the COLONEL en with MARIANNE. He is exhausted and soaked. MARIANNE is du with cold and fatigue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not hurt--but we must get her  warm!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MR PALMER take MARIANNE from BRANDON and go  upstairs, with CHARLOTTE in pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great house sits in darkness. A sense of foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is in her nightgown, knocking at a door. MR PALMER answers in his nightshirt, astonished to have been summon out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Marianne may need a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR PALMER and CHARLOTTE are sitting at the breakfast tabl BRANDON is pacing. The rain has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll wear yourself out, Colonel!  Do not worry! A day or two in bed  will soon set her to rights!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can rely upon Harris, Colonel. I  have never found a better physician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter ELINOR with DR HARRIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent) What is your diagnosis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is an infectious fever that has  taken far more serious hold than I  would have expected in one so young.  I would recommend the hasty removal  of your child, Mr Palmer--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE runs out of the room screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Bunting! Mrs Bunting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLOTTE is getting into their carriage with MRS BUNTING and BABY THOMAS. MR PALMER is on the steps with ELINOR. H takes her hand and looks at her with real sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Miss Dashwood, I am more  sorry than I can say. If you would  prefer me to stay I am at your  service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is touched to find this warm heart beneath his fro exterior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Palmer, that is very kind. But  Colonel Brandon and Dr Harris will  look after us. Thank you for  everything you have done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR PALMER nods, presses her hand, and walks down the step to the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON sits head in hands. His ghosts have come to haunt him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is tossing and turning in the bed. DR HARRIS is  trying to take her pulse. He looks up at ELINOR, who is  watching anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is not doing as well as I would  like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR exits the bedroom to find BRANDON outside. She jum

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, you have done so much  already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me an occupation, Miss Dashwood,  or I shall run mad. He is dangerously  quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She would be easier if her mother  were here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Barton is but eight hours  away. If I make no stop, you may see  us early tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes ELINOR's hand and kisses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your hands I know she will be  safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON mounts his horse, turns to look at the house for moment, and then spurs it violently forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is by the window, having watched BRANDON's departu DR HARRIS is by MARIANNE's side. He turns to ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double the number of drops and I  will return as soon as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house stands in virtual darkness with only a dim ligh issuing from one of the upper rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON riding fast, his cape billowing out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE's eyes glitter with the fever. ELINOR wipes her  brow. Suddenly she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking at the end of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, look, Elinor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no one there, dearest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Papa. Papa has come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks fearfully towards the end of the bed. MARIAN tries to smile with her cracked lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dearest Papa!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dead are coming for the dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR, her eyes red from watching, wipes MARIANNE's temp DR HARRIS takes her pulse and looks at ELINOR anxiously. silence is worse than any utterance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is very still. MARIANNE is pale as wax. DR HARRI puts on his coat. ELINOR looks at him fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must fetch more laudanum. I cannot  pretend, Miss Dashwood, that your  sister's condition is not very  serious. You must prepare yourself.  I will return very shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE lies in the grip of her fever. ELINOR sits watch her. Slowly she rises and walks to the bed. When she spea her tone is very practical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, Marianne, please try--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, almost unconsciously, she starts to heave with sobs, wrenched out of her, full of anguish and heartbreak and all the more painful for being tearless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne, please try--I cannot--I  cannot do without you. Oh, please, I  have tried to bear everything else-- I will try--but please, dearest,  beloved Marianne, do not leave me  alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She falls to her knees by the bed, gulping for breath, ta MARIANNE's hand and kissing it again and again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shimmer of light appears on the rim of the horizon.  Somewhere a lark breaks into clear untroubled song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR HARRIS sits slumped in a chair. MARIANNE lies motionle ELINOR rises with difficulty from the bedside and goes to the window. She is white as paper. The lark sings. Then,  from behind, comes the faintest of whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elinor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR turns with a cry. DR HARRIS springs from his seat examines MARIANNE. He then turns to ELINOR with a smile o relief and nods. At that moment the sound of carriage whe is heard on the gravel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON helps MRS DASHWOOD, who is weak with exhaustion a distress, out of the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR hurls herself down the stairs. She reaches the doo just as BRANDON and MRS DASHWOOD enter and practically sw into her mother's arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma! She is out of danger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on MARIANNE's face as MRS DASHWOOD kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, there, my love, my Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE opens her eyes and smiles at her mother. MRS DAS takes her gently into her arms. MARIANNE suddenly looks  anxious. She is too weak to move her head. She whispers w urgent effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Elinor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am here, dearest, I am here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks at her with deep relief. Behind the DASHWO BRANDON stands at the door, unwilling to intrude on this  intimacy. He wipes his eyes and turns away. MARIANNE sees and whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Brandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRANDON turns back, his eyes full of tears. MARIANNE look at him for a moment. Then, very quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cottage nestles in the first buds of spring. A piece rope hangs down from the branches of a tree in the garden It starts to wave about wildly and we see MARGARET emergi and climbing down. She has built herself a new tree-house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What though the sea with waves  continuall Doe eate the earth, it is  no more at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE is on the sofa by the window. She is pale,  convalescent and calm. Different somehow. She listens int as BRANDON reads her the poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nor is the earth the lesse, or loseth  aught. For whatsoever from one place  doth fall, Is with the tide unto  another brought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move back to find MRS DASHWOOD and ELINOR at the other end of the room, sewing peacefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He certainly is nor so dashing as  Willoughby but he has a far more  pleasing countenance. There was always  a something, if you remember, in  Willoughby's eyes at times which I  did not like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR listens patiently as her mother rewrites history. cut back to BRANDON as he finishes reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'For there is nothing lost, but may  be found, if sought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at MARIANNE. A soul-breathing glance. She smi as he closes the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we continue tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--for I must away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away? Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing) That I cannot tell you. It is a  secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impulsive) But you will not stay away long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on BRANDON's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MARIANNE are out on a walk. They go very slowl MARIANNE leaning on ELINOR's arm. Their mood is loving,  companion able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR and MARIANNE walk on. Suddenly, MARIANNE stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She indicates a spot on the ground but ELINOR can see not and is momentarily alarmed. MARIANNE gazes at the ground breathes in deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There I fell, and there I first saw  Willoughby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor Willoughby. He will always regret  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But does it follow that, had he chosen  me, he would have been content?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks at MARIANNE, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would have had a wife he loved  but no money--and might soon have  learned to rank the demands of his  pocket-book far above the demands of  his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR regards MARIANNE admiringly. MARIANNE smiles sadly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If his present regrets are half as  painful as mine, he will suffer  enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you compare your conduct with  his?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I compare it with what it ought  to have been. I compare it with yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our situations were very different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My illness has made me consider the  past. I saw in my own behaviour  nothing but imprudence--and worse. I  was insolent and unjust to everyone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR tries to stem the flow but MARIANNE continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --but you--you I wronged above all.  Only I knew your heart and its sorrows  but even then I was never a grain  more compassionate. I brought my  illness upon myself--I wanted to  destroy myself. And had I succeeded,  what misery should I have caused  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR embraces her. They stand with their arms round one another in silence for a moment. Then MARIANNE breaks awa and speaks with great good humour and energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall mend my ways! I shall no  longer worry others nor torture  myself. I am determined to enter on  a course of serious study---Colonel  Brandon has promised me the run of  his library and I shall read at least  six hours a day. By the end of the  year I expect to have improved my  learning a very great deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMAS is sitting on the back of a local wagon, holding a basket of food. He jumps off near the cottage and waves a cheery farewell the DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the accounts book, covered in blots and crossed- sums. Pull up to reveal MARIANNE labouring over it. Her  sickness has left her slightly short-sighted and she uses pince-nez that makes her look like an owl. ELINOR is sewing and MRS DASHWOOD is snoozing. MARGARET g up and looks over MARIANNE's shoulder. She frowns at the  spider's web of ink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll go blind if you're not careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETSY brings in coals for the fire. MRS DASHWOOD rouses  herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Thomas back from Exeter, Betsy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am--he brung back two lovely  fillets for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD looks nervously at ELINOR like a child who h been caught out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beef is far less expensive in Exeter,  and anyway they are for Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR laughs and rolls her eyes to heaven. BETSY turns o her way out to remark:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixpence a piece, Miss Dashwood. Oh,  and he says Mr Ferrars is married,  but I suppose you know that, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a stunned silence. Everyone looks at ELINOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetch Thomas to us, Betsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BETSY leaves. They all sit very still. MARGARET is about talk to ELINOR about it but MARIANNE stops her. THOMAS en

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg pardon, Miss Dashwood, but they  was the cheapest in the market--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a very good price, Thomas,  well done. Would you be so kind as  to build up the fire a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved) Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that Mr Ferrars was  married, Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMAS builds up the fire as he answers. He tells the sto with pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen him myself, ma'am, and his  lady too, Miss Lucy Steele as was-- they were stopping in a chaise at  the New London Inn. I happened to  look up as I passed the chaise and I  see it was Miss Steele. So I took  off my hat and she inquired after  you, ma'am, and all the young ladies,  especially Miss Dashwood, and bid me  I should give you her and Mr Ferrars's  best compliments and service and how  they'd be sure to send you a piece  of the cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was Mr Ferrars in the carriage with  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am--I just seen him leaning  back in it, but he did not look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR screws up her courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she cannot continue. MARIANNE glances at her  compassionately and takes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Mrs Ferrars seem well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Marianne--she said how she  was vastly contented and, since she  was always a very affable young lady,  I made free to wish her joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods and leaves, confused by the silent atmosphere. EL sits for a moment, then gets up and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR is standing by the gate, looking out. MRS DASHWOOD comes down the path to join her. She links arms with ELIN and they stand in silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father once told me not to allow  you to neglect yourself. Now I find  that it is I who have neglected you  most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mamma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have. We all have. Marianne  is right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am very good at hiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we must observe you more closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a painful difference between  the expectation of an unpleasant  event and its final certainty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD squeezes ELINOR's arm tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse and cart are jogging along. The cart contains a l object tied down and covered with canvas. The DRIVER whis tunelessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is standing on the kitchen table while ELINOR an MARIANNE pin a piece of material around the bottom of her skirt to lengthen it. Suddenly there is a commotion upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne! Marianne! Come and see  what is coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone runs out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMAS and the CARTER are carrying a small piano up the p

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They carry the piano into the parlour and to the DASHWOOD joyful astonishment it fits perfectly. MRS DASHWOOD reads out the letter that has accompanied it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'At last I have found a small enough  instrument to fir the parlour. I  expect to follow it in a day or two,  by which time I expect you to have  learned the enclosed. Your devoted  friend, Christopher Brandon.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD hands MARIANNE the letter and a broadsheet s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must like you very much, Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not just for me! It is for all  of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the same, she looks conscious of the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET is up her tree. ELINOR is pulling weeds. MRS DAS is sitting on a stool working on MARGARET's dress and  listening to the strains of the new song which MARIANNE i singing in the cottage. All of a sudden, MRS DASHWOOD ris shielding her eyes with her hand. She walks down to the g looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is Colonel Brandon! Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The piano stops. MARIANNE comes out and they all gather a the gate to watch for the rider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their POV of a HORSEMAN in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not think it is the Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be. He said he would arrive  today. You must play him the new  song, Marianne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly there is a yell from MARGARET's tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARGARET practically throws herself out of the tree onto grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Edward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women look at each other in complete consternation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm. We must be calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tense silence reigns. Everyone tries to busy themselves.  BETSY enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Ferrars for you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD follows her in, looking white and agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Edward! What a pleasure to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Dashwood. Miss Marianne. Margaret.  Miss Dashwood. I hope I find you all  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bows formally to each of them, lingering on ELINOR, wh is looking firmly at her lap. He looks anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Edward, we are all very  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause while they all search for an appropriate remark. Finally MARGARET decides to have a go at polite  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have been enjoying very fine  weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE looks at her incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am glad of it. The... the roads  were very dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD decides to bite the bullet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him her hand) May I wish you great joy, Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand somewhat confusedly and accepts her off of a seat. There is an awful silence. MARIANNE tries to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you have left Mrs Ferrars  well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tolerably, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is another bone-crunching pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I--But EDWARD cannot seem to find  any words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mrs Ferrars at the new parish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD looks extremely confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No--my mother is in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He plucks up the courage to look at ELINOR again and is  evidently not much comforted by what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant to enquire after Mrs Edward  Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD colours. He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have not heard--the news--I  think you mean my brother--you mean  Mrs Robert Ferrars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all stare at him in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Robert Ferrars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR has frozen. EDWARD rises and goes to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I received a letter from Miss  Steele--or Mrs Ferrars, I should say-- communicating the... the transfer of  her affections to my brother Robert.  They were much thrown together in  London, I believe, and... and in  view of the change in my  circumstances, I felt it only fair  that Miss Steele be released from  our engagement. At any rate, they  were married last week and are now  in Plymouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR rises suddenly, EDWARD turns and they stand lookin at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you--are not married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR bursts into tears. The shock of this emotional  explosion stuns everyone for a second and then MARIANNE m an executive decision. Wordlessly, she takes MARGARET's h and leads her and MRS DASHWOOD out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three DASHWOODS come into the garden, still holding h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR cannot stop crying. EDWARD comes forward, very slo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elinor! I met Lucy when I was very  young. Had I had an active profession,  I should never have felt such an  idle, foolish inclination. At Norland  my behaviour was very wrong. But I  convinced myself you felt only  friendship for me and it was my heart  alone that I was risking. I have  come with no expectations. Only to  profess, now that I am at liberty to  do so, that my heart is and always  will be yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELINOR looks at him, her face streaked with tears of rele emotion, of pain and of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIANNE and MRS DASHWOOD are stamping about in the garde trying to keep warm. MARGARET has climbed into her tree-h The branches rustle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting next to her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret, come down!/Is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scolding) Margaret! Will you stop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marianne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's kneeling down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS DASHWOOD can't help herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Is he? Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and MARIANNE look at each other joyfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The figures of EDWARD and ELINOR can be seen walking, in  deep conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The lovers walk slowly, their heads almost touchin their words low and intimate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother, I suppose, will hardly  be less angry with Robert for marrying  Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more so since she settled the  money upon him so irrevocably--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --no doubt because she had run out  of sons to disinherit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her family fluctuates at an alarming  rate. Then, in London, when you told  me of the Colonel's offer, I became  convinced that you wanted me to marry  Lucy and that--well, that you and  Colonel Brandon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Colonel Brandon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall not forget attempting to  thank him for making it possible for  me to marry the woman I did not love  while convinced he had designs upon  the woman I did--do--love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARD stops walking. He looks at ELINOR and realises he stand it no longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you--can you--excuse me--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her face in his hands and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of VILLAGE CHILDREN run down the hillside towards the church waving ribbons and dressed in their Sunday bes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large wedding party is gathered outside the church. The entire village is present--CHILDREN, FARMERS, LABOURERS,  SHOPKEEPERS, and all our PRINCIPALS. We see MRS JENNINGS a gigantic mauve bonnet, CHARLOTTE and MR PALMER, SIR JOH MRS DASHWOOD, MARGARET, THOMAS, JOHN and FANNY, who is dr in a fantastically inappropriate concoction, and some MEN regimental uniform. The path to the church is strewn with wild flowers and  everyone holds a bunch of their own. The church bells sta to peal, and a great cheer goes up as the door opens and  BETSY comes out holding the bridal cake aloft. The bride and groom appear: MARIANNE, in white lawn, and  COLONEL BRANDON in full uniform. Behind them come EDWARD his parson's garb and, on his arm, ELINOR as matron of ho CLOSE on them as they watch the party moving away. MARIAN and BRANDON make their way forwards, everyone throws thei flowers over them, whooping and singing. An open carriage decked with bridal wreaths comes to meet them, and BRANDO lifts MARIANNE in. His melancholy air is all but gone and radiates joyful life and vigour. MARIANNE also looks extr happy - but there is a gravity to her joy that makes her  seem much older. According to the custom of the time, BRANDON throws a lar handful of six pences into the crowd, and the VILLAGE CHI jump and dive for them. The coins spin and bounce, catching the sun like jewels. hits FANNY in the eye. She reels and falls over backwards into a gorse bush. CAM pulls back as the wedding processi makes its glorious way from the church. We draw away into the surrounding countryside. Then we see, on the far edge of frame, very small, a MAN  sitting on a white horse, watching. It is WILLOUGHBY. As draw back further still, he slowly pulls the horse around and moves off in the opposite direction.
